revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} [[File:Jan van de Cappelle (Dutch - Shipping in a Calm at Flushing with a States General Yacht Firing a Salute - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|360px|''Shipping in a Calm at Flushing with a States General Yacht Firing a Salute'', 1649]]
'''Jan van de Cappelle''' (or '''Joannes / van der / Capelle''' in various combinations; 25 January 1626 (baptized) – 22 December 1679 (buried))<ref>"Capelle", which he sometimes used himself, is also found. His signatures may also use "Capel" and "Joannes". MacLaren, 73</ref> was a [[Dutch Golden Age painter]] of seascapes and winter landscapes, also notable as an industrialist and art collector. He is "now considered the outstanding marine painter of 17th century Holland".<ref name="Grove">Grove</ref> He lived all his life in [[Amsterdam]], and as well as working as an artist spent much, or most,<ref>In 1666 he gave his occupation to a [[notary]] as "dyer". <!--According to G. Schwarz Van de Cappelle produced dye.--></ref> of his time helping to manage his father Franchoy's large dyeworks, which specialized in the expensive [[dye]] [[carmine]], and which he eventually inherited in 1674. Presumably because of this dual career, there are fewer than 150 surviving paintings,<ref name="Grove" /> a relatively small number for the industrious painters of the Dutch Golden Age. His marine paintings usually show estuary or river scenes rather than the open sea, and the water is always very calm, allowing it to act as a mirror reflecting the cloud formations above; this effect was Cappelle's speciality.
==Life== [[File:Jan van de Cappelle 001.jpg|thumb|left|''The Home Fleet Saluting the State Barge'', 1650, a "parade" picture. 64 × 92.5 cm (25.20 × 36.42 in)]]
His father (1594–1674) was a cloth-dyer, his mother came from Rotterdam; they married in 1622 in Amsterdam. Joannes' baptism is recorded in the [[Nieuwe Kerk (Amsterdam)|Nieuwe Kerk]], Amsterdam on 25 January 1626.<ref>Jeroen Giltay en Jan Kelch, Lof der Zeevaart, de Hollandse zeeschilders van de 17de eeuw (Rotterdam, 1996), pp. 187; Birthcertificate Amsterdam City Archive [https://stadsarchief.amsterdam.nl/archieven/archiefbank/indexen/doopregisters/zoek/search.nl.pl?v1=Fran*&b1=&a1=%3Fap*&r1=1&v2=&b2=&a2=&r2=3&d1=20&m1=01&y1=1620&d2=01&m2=02&y2=1640&rs=0&x=57&y=7]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> He was described (by [[Gerbrand van den Eeckhout]]) as a self-taught artist, but probably received some form of training from [[Simon de Vlieger]], whose style he copied or is closest to his early paintings, and perhaps other masters such as [[Willem van de Velde the Elder]]. He received the [[poorter|citizenship]] of Amsterdam on 24 July 1653, an essentially honorific ceremony for one of the city elite.<ref>MacLaren, 73, Grove.</ref> A few months before, on 2 February 1653, he had married Annetje Jansdr. Grotingh, the daughter of a bricklayer. Van de Cappelle was a very wealthy man who never needed to rely on his painting for his livelihood,<ref name="Grove"/> and it is not known if he joined the city's [[Guild of Saint Luke]], or the separate "brotherhood of painters" founded in 1653.<ref>Dutch Culture in a European Perspective: 1650, hard-won unity Door Willem Frijhoff,Marijke Spies [https://books.google.com/books?id=6yFZWojD6HwC&pg=PA446]</ref> Whether he sold his work, or how he did so, is unclear. [[File:Wintergezicht Rijksmuseum SK-A-4043.jpeg|thumbnail|Winterlandscape, Rijksmuseum <!-- SK-A-4043 -->]][[File:Jan van de Capelle.jpg|thumb|''A Calm'', 1654]] [[Abraham Bredius]] suggested Van de Cappelle was a friend of [[Rembrandt]],<ref>Bredius, A. (1892) De schilder Johannes van de Capelle, p. 29. In: Oud-Holland 10., see also Michel 62 and most writers</ref> at whose insolvency sales in 1656 and 1658 he was a large buyer, and who painted portraits of him and his wife. It has been speculated that he may have used his business contacts to help obtain the commission for Rembrandt's last, and financially very useful, group portrait commission, the [[Syndics of the Drapers' Guild (Rembrandt)|Syndics of the Drapers' Guild]] of 1662.<ref>Michel, 156</ref>
His earliest dated painting is an important and already highly accomplished one from 1645, and only one is dated in the 1660s.<ref>MacLaren, pp. 74, 76; this is NG 966, where the last digit is unreadable. Another painting, possibly not authentic, is said to have a date of 1671 or 1675.</ref> From this most authors assume he devoted his later years to his business, in which his brother Franchois also worked. In May 1661 he bought a house in the Koestraat,<ref>[http://amsterdaminsite.nl/burgo.en/J1954004.HTM View on Koestraat]</ref> near [[Nieuwmarkt]], moving from the even more expensive [[Keizersgracht]].<ref>[http://amsterdaminsite.nl/grachtw.en/J2956701.HTM View on Keizersgracht]</ref><!--now nr 316 near Beerenstraat--><ref>The purchase of the house is surprising. Liedtke suggests it had to do with the distance to the dye works. Liedtke, W. (2008) Dutch Paintings in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, p. 120. Yale University Press. New Haven and London.</ref> The house with a garden, next to a school, was sold by a son of [[Jan Pieterszoon Sweelinck|Sweelinck]], and in the deed of purchase van de Cappelle is simply called ''schilder'' (painter) and not a master painter.<ref>Breen, J.C. (1913) De woning van [[Jan van der Heyden]] in de Koestraat met eenige bijzonderheden uit de geschiedenis deezer straat. In: Yearbook Amstelodamum, p. 111. Being a "Mr schilder" would mean he was admissioned as a master in the painters guild.{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}}</ref>
His wife predeceased him in 1677, and van de Cappelle himself was buried in the Nieuwe Kerk on 22 December 1679. He left seven children.<ref name="Grove and MacLaren">Grove and MacLaren</ref> The inventory of his property at death has survived and is the main source of information about his impressive art collection. It took seven months to list all.<ref>After the death of his son, also called Jan, his share of the collection was dispersed. One large sale was on 6, 7 and 8 November 1709. See ''Dutch drawings in the Pierpont Morgan Library, Volume 1''; Dudok van Heel, S.A.C. (1975) Honderdvijftig advertenties van kunstverkopingen uit veertig jaargangen van de Amsterdamsech Courant 1672-1711, p. 171. In: Yearbook Amstelodamum.</ref> He left his children six houses,<!--<ref>Three houses were owned by his wife. </ref>--> a country house south of [[Loenen aan de Vecht|Loenen]] on the river [[Vecht (Utrecht)]], a pleasure yacht, "44 bags of ducats", silk and bonds together valued at 92,720 guilders.<ref>Bredius, A. (1892) De schilder Johannes van de Capelle, p. 26-40. In: Oud-Holland 10. An English translation of his inventory is in: Russell, M. (1975). <!--In: Liedtke, W. (2008) Dutch Paintings in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, p. 119. Yale University Press. New Haven and London.--></ref> A lengthy list of the items from his splendid wardrobe was made, (including his [[purple|violet]] stockings)<ref>Reprinted [https://books.google.com/books?id=WEQy3xkbU9cC&pg=PA162 here] Inventory of clothes App II, Q, pp 348-9</ref> as well as a list of his large and important art collection.<ref name="Grove and MacLaren"/>
==Works== [[File:Cappelle, Calm.jpg|thumb|''A Calm'', 1650–1655]]
The majority of his works are marine or river views, nearly always with several vessels, but he also left a number of small winter landscapes somewhat in the manner of [[Aert van der Neer]];<ref>MacLaren, 73 says "about forty" winter landscapes, but this seems outdated or a mistake. Grove ("fewer than twenty") and more recent sources give far fewer - see the list given by [http://www.oldmasters.net/nsa-cappelle-winter.html Lindsay Fine Art] who recognise only about fifteen]</ref> these all seem to date between 1652 and 1654.<ref>Richard Green. One recorded as dated 1644 is untraced, per Grove.</ref> His seascapes (using the term loosely) may be large or small; the nine examples in the [[National Gallery, London]], the largest group in a single collection, vary between 122 x 154.5 cm (NG 967: 48 x 61 inches) and 34.8 x 48.1 cm (NG 865: 14 x 19 inches).<ref>MacLaren, 73-79, or see online link below</ref>
He had no interest in rough seas or cloudless skies,<ref>A "Storm" mentioned in his inventory is untraced</ref> showing large cloudy skies, with the horizon low, about 15-20% of the way up the vertical axis. The clouds are often mirrored in the dead calm water, although light ripples may be shown. As is often the case in Dutch seascapes, there is often a warship or "statenjacht" ("States yacht"), an official yacht used for transport, official salutes and other business. The edge of the composition often slices through vessels, leaving them half seen. Van de Cappelle painted many ''parade'' marine subjects, depicting "a formal gathering of ships for a ceremonial occasion".<ref name="Grove" /> Other paintings, mostly smaller and of less busy subjects, a type often called "calms", show "an all-pervading luminous atmosphere that softens all outlines and unifies forms and local colours",<ref name="Grove" /> or as [[Kenneth Clark]] puts it, "When sky was reflected on water, there was achieved that unity of luminous atmosphere which is ... the whole point of van de Capelle and van de Velde".<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=uNS87UG0hRwC&pg=PA31 ''Landscape into Art'', 31]</ref> In his early works he followed the muted palette of the "tonal school", but enlived with local highlights of bright colour, but moved in his later works to "a warmer golden tonality, exceptionally allowing himself a greater colouristic exuberance when setting the rosy glow of a sunset sky against water of a deep turquoise blue, as in the ''River Scene with Sailing Vessels'' ([[Rotterdam]], [[Boymans–van Beuningen Museum]])".<ref name="Grove" /> According to his leading scholar, Margarita Russell, "More than any other artist of his time, with the exception only of Rembrandt, van de Cappelle was a painter of light".<ref name="Grove" />
Cappelle made a small number of etchings; only two signed ones of landscapes are now firmly attributed to him.<ref>Grove - Hollstein gives him nine, but most of these are now not regarded as his.</ref> Fewer than twenty of the nearly 750 of his own drawings in the 1680 inventory have survived identifiably.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=nMnqAAAAMAAJ&q=Jan+van+de+Cappelle+inventory&dq=Jan+van+de+Cappelle+inventory&cd=4]</ref>
==Art collection== [[File:Frans Hals portrait Norton Simon.jpg|thumb|This painting by Frans Hals was formerly considered to be the lost portrait of Jan van de Cappelle]] [[File:Rembrandt.fallhut.jpg|thumb|One of van de Cappelle's 500 Rembrandt drawings]] [[File:CAPELLE Jan van de Winter Landscape.jpg|thumb|''Winter Landscape'']]
He had one of the largest art collections of his day, with 192<ref>Rooses, M. (1898) DE HOLLANDSCHE MEESTERS [https://www.elseviermaandschrift.nl/EGM/1898/07/18980701/EGM-18980701-0179/story.pdf] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924000148/http://www.elseviermaandschrift.nl/EGM/1898/07/18980701/EGM-18980701-0179/story.pdf |date=2015-09-24 }}. The inventory of Capelle's estate was first published by Abraham Bredius, also in [http://english.rkd.nl/Activities/Publications_by_the_RKD/Oud_Holland/default_Oud_Holland ''Oud Holland'']{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> paintings and over 7,000 drawings,<ref name="Grove" /> nearly all Dutch with a few Flemish works, and concentrating heavily on his own specialisms of marine painting and winter landscapes. He had portraits of himself by both Rembrandt (one of a pair with his wife) and [[Frans Hals]], and he is the only person known to have been painted by both of the greatest Dutch portraitists.<ref>Slive, 220</ref> However, if they survive the identity of both paintings has been lost. The Rembrandt was claimed to be a portrait of an artist of 1648, once at [[Castle Howard]],<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=_hrOixWVE6gC&pg=PA62 Rembrandt]</ref> and in 1961 [[Norton Simon]] bought a Hals then called a portrait of Cappelle, but now just ''Portrait of a Young Man''.<ref>[http://www.nortonsimon.org/collections/browse_title.php?id=M.1972.4.P Norton Simon Museum]; and [https://books.google.com/books?id=ELP2haHL69MC&pg=PA44 Simon's purchase]</ref> There were also portraits by [[Gerbrandt van den Eeckhout]] and [[Jan van Noordt]], also untraced.<ref name="Grove" />
The collection had major groups as follows:<ref>see note at end of section for all these</ref> *Rembrandt: 7 paintings and five portfolios with over 500 drawings,<ref>For drawings see note at end of section. For the paintings, apart from the pair of portraits, NG 1400, a unique [[grisaille]] study for an [[etching]] of the ''[[Ecce Homo]]'', matches one of the inventory items. MacLaren, 346-349; [http://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/paintings/rembrandt-ecce-homo National Gallery online]</ref> including 56 "[[history painting|histories]]", an album of 135 drawings of women and children, and 300 landscape drawings - almost all those known of the last two types. This was the largest group of Rembrandt drawings ever owned by a collector.<ref>[https://www.jstor.org/stable/25142479 JSTOR]''Four Dutch Landscape Drawings'', Louise S. Richards, The Bulletin of the Cleveland Museum of Art, Vol. 48, No. 10 (Dec., 1961), pp. 266-270. For their later history, see [https://books.google.com/books?id=qpu-UrUOgOkC&pg=PA250 Wedmore]</ref> * [[Simon de Vlieger]]: 9 paintings and over 1,300 drawings including one unfinished painting,<ref>One of them is described in the inventory as "nr. 5 Een gedootverwde dito van Simon de Vlieger" . ("ditto" refers to the subject of the painting listed under "nr. 4 Een gedootverwde see van den Overleden" = Jan van der Capelle. The word "onvolledig" means literally "not complete" in this case it means probably " gedoodverfd" (dead colour: the first layers of paints –fairly monotone in shade- applied by the artist). Rijksbureau voor Kunsthistorische Documentatie RKD/Netherlands Institute for Art History</ref> *[[Jan van Goyen]]: 10 paintings and over 400 drawings *[[Jan Porcellis]]: 16 paintings *[[Hendrick Avercamp]]: paintings and nearly 900 drawings *[[Hercules Segers]]: 5 paintings, a large proportion of his known output and perhaps bought from Rembrandt. *There were seven paintings listed, one unfinished, made by van de Cappelle himself,<ref>Bredius, A. (1892) De schilder Johannes van de Capelle, p. 32-37. In: Oud-Holland 10. Two landscapes (106, 107), a sea after Porcellis (116) a storm (119), a [[Schenkenschans]] after de Vlieger and a model (?) (167)</ref> but between 800 drawings, perhaps around 1150, including works described as copies by him after Porcellis and de Vlieger *Several [[Artist's portfolio|portfolios]] with drawings by [[Esias van de Velde]] (88), [[Pieter van Laer]] (41), [[Willem Buytewech]] (86), [[Pieter de Molijn]] (57), and [[Allaert van Everdingen]] (52)
The collection included paintings by [[Jan Lievens]], [[Hendrick Goltzius]], [[Paulus Potter]], [[Adam Elsheimer]], [[Dürer]], [[David Vinckboons]], [[Pieter Aertsen]], [[Hans Holbein the Younger|Holbein]], [[Jacob Pynas]], [[Jan Miense Molenaer]], [[Maarten van Heemskerck]], [[Frans Floris]], [[Philips Koninck]] and [[Pieter Lastman]]; Flemish artists represented included [[Rubens]] (three paintings), [[Van Dyck]], [[Jacob Jordaens]], [[Pieter Bruegel the Elder]] and [[Adriaen Brouwer]]. Van de Capelle owned 83 drawings by [[Jan den Uyl]]. The large groups of drawings by individual artists suggest that he had bought their studio stock of working drawings complete after their death or retirement. The Rembrandt drawings were probably acquired at his insolvency sales in 1656 and 1658.<ref>Details variously from Grove, MacLaren, Slive and [http://www.rembrandtpainting.net/about_rembrandt_drawings.htm Slive on Rembrandt drawings]; Crenshaw, 162, note 14. The inventory was first printed by Bredius in 1898, and is reprinted in Russell's monograph.</ref>
==Reputation and location of works== Van de Cappelle had a considerable influence on painters of both marine and winter subjects, including [[Willem van de Velde the Younger]] in the former group, [[Jan van Kessel (Amsterdam)|Jan van Kessel]] in the latter, and [[Hendrick Dubbels]] in both.<ref name="Grove" />
Van de Cappelle does not seem to have participated much in the commercial art world of his day, which may account for his absence from the all the contemporary collections of artists' biographies such as the over 500 lives by [[Arnold Houbraken]]'s in his ''De groote schouwburg der Nederlandsche kunstschilders en schilderessen'' – "The Great Theatre of Dutch Painters", (1718–21). [[Joachim von Sandrart]] (1606–1688) and [[Samuel van Hoogstraten]] (1627–1678) also overlook him. This was also probably partly the result of the biographers' following contemporary prejudices against marine, landscape, and [[still life]] painting, regarded as the lowest in the [[hierarchy of genres]]. He was for long perhaps better known in England than Holland, and the distribution of his works still reflects this.{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}}
The largest collection of his work is the nine paintings in London, as mentioned above. There are works in the [[Rijksmuseum]], the [[Mauritshuis]],<ref>[http://www.thearttribune.com/Acquisition-of-a-seascape-by-Jan.html Art Tribune] Mauritshuis acquisition</ref> [[Rijksmuseum Twenthe]], in the [[Getty Museum]], [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]],<ref>[http://www.metmuseum.org/works_of_art/collection_database/european_paintings/a_state_yacht_and_other_craft_in_calm_water/objectView.aspx?&OID=110000275&collID=11&vw=0 MMA]</ref> [[National Museum of Wales]], [[Detroit Institute of Arts]], [[Manchester Art Gallery]] (3), [[Nationalmuseum]], [[Wallraf-Richartz Museum]] and elsewhere.<ref>[http://www.artcyclopedia.com/artists/cappelle_jan_van_de.html Artcyclopedia]</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist|2}}
==References== {{Commons category}} *Richard Green Gallery, [https://web.archive.org/web/20110718214421/http://www.richard-green.com/media/winter-landscape-with-skaters-and-colf-player-frozen-waterway-village-DesktopDefault.aspx?tabid=6&tabindex=5&objectid=248120 A ''Winter Landscape'' and biography] *"Grove", Russell Margarita, ''Jan van de Cappelle'' in [[Grove Art Online]], accessed April 1, 2010 *[[Neil MacLaren]], ''The Dutch School, 1600–1800, Volume I'', 1991, National Gallery Catalogues, National Gallery, London, {{ISBN|0-947645-99-3}} *Michel, Emil, ''[https://archive.org/stream/rembrandthislife02michuoft/rembrandthislife02michuoft_djvu.txt Rembrandt, His Life, his Work, and his Time]'', Heinemann, 1894 *[[Seymour Slive]], ''Dutch Painting, 1600–1800'', Yale UP, 1995,{{ISBN|0-300-07451-4}}
==Further reading== *Russell, Margarita. ''Jan van de Cappelle 1624/6-1679'', Lewis, Leigh-on-Sea, 1975 {{ISBN|0-85317-029-0}}, {{ISBN|978-0-85317-029-7}}
==External links== *[https://books.google.com/books?id=6LWbImajETkC&pg=PA56 Rembrandt drawings] *[http://www.getty.edu/art/gettyguide/artMakerDetails?maker=3528 Getty Museum biography] *[http://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/artists/jan-van-de-cappelle National Gallery collection]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Cappelle, Jan van de}} [[Category:1621 births]] [[Category:1679 deaths]] [[Category:Marine artists]] [[Category:Dutch Golden Age painters]] [[Category:Dutch male painters]] [[Category:Dutch businesspeople]] [[Category:Dutch art collectors]] [[Category:Artists from Amsterdam]] [[Category:Burials at the Nieuwe Kerk (Amsterdam)]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Use South African English|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox F1 driver | image = Scheckter_Monza_1979.jpg | caption = Jody Scheckter in 1979 at [[Autodromo Nazionale Monza|Monza]] | name = Jody Scheckter | nationality = {{flagicon|ZAF|1928}} South African | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1950|1|29}} | birth_place = [[East London, Eastern Cape|East London]], South Africa | Years = {{F1|1972}} – {{F1|1980}} | Team(s) = [[McLaren]], [[Tyrrell Racing|Tyrrell]], [[Walter Wolf Racing|Wolf]], [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]] | Races = 113 (112 starts) | Championships = 1 ([[1979 Formula One season|1979]]) | Wins = 10 | Podiums = 33 | Points = 246 (255)Up until {{F1|1990}}, not all points scored by a driver contributed to their final World Championship tally (see [[List of Formula One World Championship points scoring systems|list of points scoring systems]] for more information). Numbers without parentheses are Championship points; numbers in parentheses are total points scored. | Poles = 3 | Fastest laps = 5 | First race = [[1972 United States Grand Prix]] | First win = [[1974 Swedish Grand Prix]] | Last win = [[1979 Italian Grand Prix]] | Last race = [[1980 United States Grand Prix]] }} '''Jody David Scheckter''' (born 29 January 1950) is a [[South Africa]]n former [[auto racing|motor racing]] driver. He competed in [[Formula One]] from 1972 to 1980, winning the Drivers' Championship in {{F1|1979}} with [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]]. ==Career== Scheckter was born in [[East London, Eastern Cape]], and educated at [[Selborne College]]. ===Formula One=== [[File:Scheckter Britain 1974.jpg|thumb|left|Scheckter in a [[Tyrrell 007]] at the [[1974 British Grand Prix]] at [[Brands Hatch]].]] He rapidly ascended to the ranks of Formula One after moving to Britain in 1970. His Formula 1 debut occurred at the US Grand Prix at [[Watkins Glen International|Watkins Glen]] in [[1972 Formula One season|1972]] with [[Team McLaren|McLaren]], where he ran as high as third place before spinning and finishing ninth. Immediately becoming a name to watch, he continued his development the following year, winning the [[1973 SCCA L&M Championship]] and racing five times in F1. In France, he almost won in only his third start in F1 before crashing into [[Emerson Fittipaldi]], the reigning World Champion, who said after the crash about Scheckter: "This madman is a menace to himself and everybody else and does not belong in Formula 1." In his next start, the British Grand Prix at [[Silverstone Circuit|Silverstone]], Scheckter's spin triggered a major accident which took nearly a dozen cars out of the race. The [[Grand Prix Drivers Association]] demanded his immediate banishment, which was only put off when McLaren agreed to rest their driver for four races. Scheckter's [[McLaren M23]] bore the number zero during the Canadian and American Grands Prix of 1973. Scheckter is one of only two F1 drivers to compete under this number, the other being [[Damon Hill]]. During the practice for the American event at the [[Watkins Glen International|Watkins Glen]] circuit, Frenchman [[François Cevert]], who was due to be Scheckter's Tyrrell teammate for 1974, was killed in an appalling accident at the fast uphill Esses corners. Scheckter was behind Cevert when he crashed, and he stopped his McLaren, got out of his car and attempted to help Cevert out of his destroyed Tyrrell, but the 29-year-old Frenchman had been cut in half by the circuit's poorly installed Armco barriers and was already dead. Witnessing Cevert's dreadful accident left an indelible mark on the South African and caused him to abandon his reckless ways, becoming a more mature and calculating driver as a result.http://www.formula1.com/teams_and_drivers/hall_of_fame/283/ [[File:ScheckterJody1976-07-31Tyrrell-FordP34.jpg|thumb|Scheckter in the iconic six-wheel [[Tyrrell P34]] at the [[Nürburgring]] in 1976.]] [[Tyrrell Racing|Tyrrell]] in 1974 gave him his first full-time drive in F1. Jody rewarded them with a third-place finish in the Drivers' Championship and a pair of wins in [[1974 Swedish Grand Prix|Sweden]] and [[1974 British Grand Prix|Britain]]. During the year, he scored points in eight consecutive races, one of the longer scoring streaks of the time. A slight off-year followed, although he did become the only South African to win the [[South African Grand Prix]], but his third year with the team in 1976 gave him another third-place finish in the Drivers' Championship. In that season, Tyrrell introduced the most radical car in F1 history, the innovative six-wheeled [[Tyrrell P34]]. Although he later went on record as saying the car was "a piece of junk", Scheckter gave the six-wheeler its only win on Sweden's [[Scandinavian Raceway|Anderstorp]] circuit and in his twelve races with the car, he scored points ten times. This included a thrilling race-long battle for the lead in the [[1976 United States Grand Prix|American Grand Prix]] between himself and his great friend [[James Hunt]]. Scheckter left for [[Walter Wolf (industrialist)|Walter Wolf]]'s new team in 1977 and Scheckter gave the team a win in its maiden race. He won twice more with the team and was often on the podium, but finished second on points behind a more dominant [[Niki Lauda]]. A seventh-place finish with the team in 1978 followed and he left the team after the season to join [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]] to partner [[Gilles Villeneuve]] in the team's ground effect [[Ferrari 312T|312T4]] car. Critics felt he would not get along well with the domineering management at Ferrari, but he far surpassed expectations and helped give F1's most recognisable team another Constructors' Championship, while Scheckter's consistent finishes, with three wins among them, gave him the Drivers' Championship in 1979.{{cite web|url=http://www.formula1.com/teams_and_drivers/hall_of_fame/283/|publisher=Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile|title=F1 Teams & Drivers Hall of Fame: Jody Schekter|accessdate=24 October 2007}} However, he struggled badly in his 1980 title defence, even failing to qualify for one race. After managing only two points, Scheckter announced his retirement from the team and the sport. Scheckter was the last driver to win a Drivers' Championship for Ferrari until [[Michael Schumacher]] twenty-one years later in {{F1|2000}}. ==After Formula One== ===Broadcaster=== In 1981 [[CBS Sports]] hired Scheckter as a Pit reporter for its [[F1]] coverage. Scheckter was brought in by [[ABC Sports|ABC's]] [[Wide World of Sports (U.S. TV series)|Wide World Of Sports]] as a Pit reporter for the [[1983 Monaco Grand Prix]]. Scheckter was a guest commentator for ITV during the [[1999 San Marino Grand Prix]], replacing [[Martin Brundle]]. ===Other interests=== In 1981, Scheckter won the World [[Superstars]] competition in Key Biscayne, Florida. He defeated athletes such as [[Russ Francis]], [[Renaldo Nehemiah]], [[Peter Mueller (athlete)|Peter Mueller]], [[Rick Barry]], [[Gaétan Boucher]] and [[Andy Ripley]]. In 1983 he was inducted into the [[International Jewish Sports Hall of Fame]]. After Scheckter's retirement, he founded [[FATS Inc]], a company which built firearms training simulators for military, law enforcement and security organisations. The sale of the company provided funds to allow Scheckter to help the racing careers of his sons [[Tomas Scheckter|Tomas]] and [[Toby Scheckter|Toby]]. Tomas raced in the [[Indy Racing League]] where he won two races. Scheckter's brother, [[Ian Scheckter|Ian]], also raced in F1 for a few years. In 2004 Scheckter was reunited with his championship-winning Ferrari at the South African two-seater F1x2 Charity Grand Prix at [[Kyalami]] in South Africa. ===Present=== Scheckter now spends his time as a [[Biodynamic agriculture|biodynamic farmer]],{{cite news|title=Formula One's Jody Scheckter Turns to Meat|publisher=foodmanufacture.co.uk|url=http://www.foodmanufacture.co.uk/news/fullstory.php/aid/4388/Formula_One's_Jody_Scheckter_turns_to_meat.html|date=1 March 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071223001440/http://www.foodmanufacture.co.uk/news/fullstory.php/aid/4388/Formula_One's_Jody_Scheckter_turns_to_meat.html|archivedate=23 December 2007|df=dmy-all}} having bought [[Laverstoke Park Farm]], near [[Overton, Hampshire]], {{convert|40|mi|km|0}} west of London. As an organic farming expert, Scheckter was featured in 2005 on the Visionhealth DVD and TV documentaries "[[Asthma]]: An Integrated Approach", "[[Arthritis]]: An Integrated Approach" and "[[Diabetes]]: An Integrated Approach". On 20 November 2011, he also appeared on the ''[[Countryfile]]'' television show to make a case for [[organic food]]. Laverstoke Park Farm was also featured on BBC's "Escape To the Country" where Jody showed viewers how [[Buffalo Mozzarella]] was made. In December 2009, Scheckter announced his intention to produce a [[Biodynamic agriculture|biodynamic]] [[sparkling wine]] by 2012. In 2015 the farm was the setting for ITV's Sugar Free Farm where a group of celebrities had to go sugar free for two weeks whilst working on the farm. Embarking on the radical regime were musical theatre star [[Jane McDonald]], comedian [[Rory McGrath]], quiz mastermind and Chaser [[Mark Labbett]], actress [[Tupele Dorgu]], TOWIE's [[James Argent|James 'Arg' Argent]] and actress and singer [[Jennifer Ellison]].Lawrence, James, ''Decanter.com'' (14 December 2009). [http://www.decanter.com/news/292915.html Jody Scheckter announces Hampshire winery plans] He is married and has six children: two, [[Toby Scheckter|Toby]] and [[Tomas Scheckter|Tomas]], from his previous wife Pamela; and four, Hugo, Freddie, Ila and Poppy, from his current marriage to Clare. ==Racing record== ===Complete Formula One World Championship results=== ([[:Template:F1 driver results legend 2|key]]) (Races in '''bold''' indicate pole position; races in ''italics'' indicate fastest lap) {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; font-size:90%" |- ! {{Infobox magazine | title = Light Metal Age | image_file = 2010-April-Cover-large.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = Cover of April 2010 issue of ''Light Metal Age'' | image_caption = Cover of April 2010 issue of ''Light Metal Age'' | publisher = Ann Marie Fellom | frequency = Bimonthly | circulation = 4,000 | category = [[science]], [[materials science|materials]], [[engineering]] | company = Fellom Publishing | firstdate = May 1943 | country = [[United States]] | based = [[South San Francisco]], [[California]] | language = English | website = [http://www.lightmetalage.com www.lightmetalage.com] | issn = 0024-3345 }}
'''''Light Metal Age''''' is a technical trade magazine exclusively devoted to primary production and semi-fabrication of [[light metals]], specifically [[aluminum]], [[titanium]], [[magnesium]], [[beryllium]], and their [[alloys]]. However, the main editorial emphasis is [[aluminum]].
Published bimonthly by Fellom Publishing, ''Light Metal Age'' is distributed worldwide to primary and secondary [[smelters]]; casthouses; [[aluminum extrusion|extrusion]] operations; [[rolling mills]]; sheet, rod, and wire mills; and foundries. Recipients are executives, general managers, plant managers, technicians, metallurgists, chemists, and engineers responsible for fabrication, production, and operations in this industry.
== History == ''Light Metal Age'' was founded in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] in 1943 by Roy Fellom, Jr., owner of Fellom Publishing. Roy Fellom predicted that there would be an increased use of [[light metals]], especially [[aluminum]]. In the first issue of ''Light Metal Age'' in May 1943, he wrote a dedication explaining that the magazine was created to "herald the new LIGHT METAL ERA which shall see these most abundant basic metals brought to the service of man in all the common uses where metal is required."<ref>Fellom, Jr., Roy: "Dedication", page 4. Light Metal Age, 1(1), 1943.</ref> In 1955, Roy Fellom moved the company from Chicago to [[San Francisco]], California, where it remained until 1989 when the headquarters was moved to [[South San Francisco]], where it is now located.
Roy Fellom was recognized for his dedication to promoting the light metals industry via ''Light Metal Age'' in 1992 with the Maurice H. Roberts Award of Excellence, presented at the Fifth International Aluminum Extrusion Technology Seminar (ET ’92).
In 2000, ''Light Metal Age'' was named the official publication of the Seventh International Aluminum Extrusion Technology Seminar (ET 2000), and was again named the official publication for the subsequent seminars, ET ’04 and ET ’08.<ref>[http://www.aec.org/assets/media/LMAofficialET08.doc “Light Metal Age Named Official Publication of ET ’08”] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718121905/http://www.aec.org/assets/media/LMAofficialET08.doc |date=2011-07-18 }} (DOC), [http://www.aec.org Aluminum Extruders Council], 2007.</ref>
Roy Fellom, Jr. died in 1993. ''Light Metal Age'' is carried on by his daughter, Ann Marie Fellom.
In 2006, ''Light Metal Age'' donated Roy Fellom’s extensive library of 692 books covering all topics of light metal production to the [[List of Illinois Institute of Technology buildings|Paul V. Galvin Library]] at the [[Illinois Institute of Technology]] (IIT) in Chicago.<ref>[http://www.lightmetalage.com/whatsnew.php?item=6 "Light Metal Age Donates Metallurgical Library to IIT"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713205120/http://www.lightmetalage.com/whatsnew.php?item=6 |date=2011-07-13 }}, ''Light Metal Age'', 2006.</ref>
== Content ==
=== Articles === ''Light Metal Age'' covers primary production and semi-fabrication of [[light metals]], mainly [[aluminum]], but also [[titanium]] and [[magnesium]], as well as associated light metal processes and equipment, including DC casting, [[anodizing]], [[furnaces]] and melting, [[degassing]] and filtration, sawing, and handling. Articles are technical in nature, with the aim of being of practical use to executives, general managers, plant managers, technicians, metallurgists, chemists, and engineers working in the light metal industry.
=== Departments === * Light Metal World – offers current statistical data on aluminum production in the [[United States]] and [[Canada]], as well as a short article involving [[light metals]] in the world * Contracts & Expansions – light metals industry news * News (specific focus) – industry news published on alternating topics, such as [[Primary Aluminum]], [[Aluminum Extrusion]], Flat Rolled Aluminum, [[Titanium]], etc. * Lightweight Matters (occasional) – a lighter, applications-focused article * International [[Patent]] Calendar – a list of recent patents relevant to the light metals industry * International Aluminum Abstracts – a list of abstracts for research and technical papers * Conference Calendar – a list of upcoming conferences relevant to the light metals industry * Personalities & Plants – news items covering appointments of new personnel and awards received by individuals or companies
=== Directories === ''Light Metal Age'' also publishes four directories catering to the aluminum industry: the Directory of Primary Aluminum Equipment Manufacturers and Suppliers, the Directory of Aluminum Extrusion Equipment Manufacturers and Suppliers, the Directory of Secondary Aluminum Equipment Manufacturers and Supplers, and the Directory of Flat Rolled Aluminum Equipment Manufacturers and Suppliers. These directories are published in the February, April, August, and December issues, respectively, as well as online for free.
=== Smelter Lists === ''Light Metal Age'' produces two charts that present the nameplate and shutdown capacities of smelters by country. The lists, "Primary Aluminum Smelters of the World" and "Secondary Aluminum Smelters of the World", are updated at least once a year to keep the information up to date.
=== Online Exclusives === ''Light Metal Age'' offers articles via its website as free pdf downloads. These articles present technical information considered to be of practical value to those involved in light metal production and processing.
=== Article Archives === In addition to its bimonthly issues, ''Light Metal Age'' publishes focused compilations of articles from the magazine’s 68 years of publication, including the ''Titanium Article Archive (November 1945-August 2009)'' and the ''Magnesium Article Archive (May 1943-May 2009)''. Archives are periodically updated to incorporate recently published articles.
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.lightmetalage.com www.lightmetalage.com] * [http://www.lightmetalage.com/suppliers/ Directories of Aluminum Equipment Suppliers and Manufacturers] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110227044603/http://www.lightmetalage.com/producers_primary.php Primary Aluminum Smelters of the World] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100620091318/http://www.lightmetalage.com/producers.php Secondary Aluminum Smelters of the World]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Light Metal Age (Magazine)}} [[Category:American business magazines]] [[Category:American bimonthly magazines]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1943]] [[Category:Professional and trade magazines]] [[Category:American science and technology magazines]] [[Category:Magazines published in California]] [[Category:1943 establishments in California]] [[Category:Mining journals]]

{{multiple issues|{{refimprove|date=December 2009}} {{speculation|date=November 2016}}}}
'''Maid service''', '''cleaning service''', '''apartment cleaning''' and '''janitorial service''' are terms more modernly describing a specialized outside service, providing a specific service to individuals, businesses, fraternal clubs and associations as well residential premises
==History== Maid services may be different from what is generally thought to be the historically prevalent services performed by a [[maid]], and these services may be provided by both male and/or female individuals. [[File:Works Progress Administration maid poster cropped.jpg|thumb|right|220px|Stylized drawing of a maid on a [[Works Progress Administration]] poster]]
Once part of an elaborate hierarchy in affluent homes and profitable businesses, today a maid may be the only domestic worker that upper and even middle-income households can afford, as a household domestic-help employee. Maids perform typical domestic chores such as cooking, ironing, washing, cleaning, grocery shopping, walking the family dog, and tending to the household children.
==Socio-economic factors== In the Western world, comparatively few households can afford live-in domestic help employees, in lieu of live-in staff, a maid service is utilized as a periodic cleaner. In developing nations, differences found within income and social status between different socio-economic classes, lesser educated women, with less opportunity are believed to provide a labor source for domestic work.
Socio-economic opportunities, not being confined to any specific global location, may allow cleaning services to perform 'cleaning' as their source of business as a service.
There are thousands of residential cleaning businesses throughout the United States, United Kingdom and Canada. Historically and traditionally, cleaning was considered a woman's role, but as more and more women have joined the workforce, the time pressure on families with children has grown, so paying a service for cleaning makes sense to persons who can afford it. Additionally, many modern homeowners lack the proper knowledge to use the safest and most effective cleaning products. ==Services provided== Maids, ''per se'', perform typical domestic chores such as cooking, ironing, washing, cleaning, folding clothes, grocery shopping, walking the family dog and taking care of children. Some maid services offer hourly, daily, weekly, bi-weekly, and monthly work as well.Book Professional and trained Maids from [https://www.springcleaning.ae/ Cleaning Services] Dubai
==Reasons for use== Utilizing a maid service may be considered due to a number of personal factors, including but not limited to geographical location, social standing, lack of personal time, lack of experience. There are many reasons why individuals may consider hiring help around the house, especially with cleaning. It may, for example, prove easier for them to enjoy time with their family rather than spending time cleaning.
[[Image:Molly Maid maid car Ypsilanti Township Michigan.JPG|thumb|A maid service "maid car" used to transport maids to assignments, [[Ypsilanti Township, Michigan]]]] A maid service may be more expensive than simply hiring a part-time [[maid]], but it offers a number of advantages. Usually the service will provide not only someone to do the cleaning, but also all of the necessary cleaning supplies. Also, as a ''bona fide'' employer, the service is responsible for withholding [[Social Security (United States)|Social Security]] and other income taxes. Third, a service is [[insured]] and often [[Surety bond|bonded]], so it can be held accountable if something is [[Theft|stolen]] or missing.
==See also== * [[Au pair]] * [[Domestic worker]] * [[Footman]] * [[Foreign domestic helpers in Hong Kong]] * [[Housekeeper (domestic worker)]] * [[Nanny]] ==References== {{Reflist}}
<ref name="Maid service 2010">{{cite web | last=Maid | first=cleaning service | title=Maids Service In Qatar | website=-:Al Allam:- | date=September 12, 2010 | url=http://www.alallamcleaning.com/cleaning-maids-service-companies-qatar.php | access-date=September 16, 2018}}</ref>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Maid Service}} [[Category:Service industries]]

revision.text:
{{more footnotes|date=February 2016}}'''Management cybernetics''' is the application of [[cybernetics]] to [[management]] and [[organizations]]. "Management cybernetics" was first introduced by [[Stafford Beer]] in the late 1950s.<ref name=rosehead /> Beer developed the theory through a combination of practical applications and a series of influential books. The practical applications involved steel production, publishing and operations research in a large variety of different industries.
== Research into operations ==
As practiced by Beer, research into operations involved multidisciplinary teams seeking practical assistance for difficult managerial issues. It often involved the development of models borrowed from basic sciences and put into an isomorphic relationships with an organizational situation. Beer initially called this "[[operations research]]" (OR) but, along with [[Russell Ackoff]], became increasingly disenchanted with that term as the field transitioned into one in which a predefined set of mathematical tools was applied to well-formulated problems. Beer's critique of traditional OR, in part, was that it became a matter of experts in mathematics looking for situations that could be conformed to their methods. Beer insisted that what was needed for effective research into operations was to first understand the key dynamics within the situation and only then to select the theory or methods that would allow one to understand that situation in detail. Beer's "Decision and Control", especially chapter six, discusses the methodology in some detail.
== Viable system model ==
Viable means capable of independent existence and implies both maintaining internal stability and adaptation to a changing environment. "Internal stability" and "adaptation" can be in conflict, particularly if the relevant environment is changing rapidly, so the [[viable system model]] (VSM) is about maintaining a balance between the two such that the system is able to survive.
The VSM is a model of the structures and functions that are both necessary and sufficient for the long term survival of a system in a changing environment. Allenna Leonard, Beer's longtime partner, suggested that the most useful way to think about the VSM is as a language. The VSM is a language of viability. The VSM is a language for diagnosing organizations and managerial teams in terms of their viability or lack thereof. The VSM is also a language for designing organizations and managerial teams that will be viable.
== Syntegration ==
One of the great difficulties in managing the modern large organization is that many of the issues are far too [[complexity|complex]] for even small groups. The critical knowledge is often dispersed among a substantial number of people. Organizations are often faced with choosing between 1) very costly and time-consuming meetings of large groups or 2) making bad decisions based on an inadequate grasp of the relevant factors. Syntegration is a group method designed to solve this conundrum.
Syntegration melds a number of cybernetic principles with [[Bucky Fuller]]'s ideas on [[tensegrity]]. The initial "team [[syntegrity]]" format involved 30 people divided into 12 overlapping teams to deal with some broad and initially ill-defined issue. The teams and roles within the teams are arranged to achieve the mathematically optimum degree of resonance of information throughout the entire group. In practice, syntegration achieves a remarkable degree of shared understanding of the initial issue. In syntegrations intended to develop a plan of action, the implementation phase is usually very quick and effective, probably because of the shared understanding developed among the participants.
== Learning ==
The literature on management cybernetics is extensive. Beer wrote hundreds of papers and about ten books. Others have contributed perhaps an equal amount. [[Barry Clemson]], at Beer's urging,{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} wrote an introduction to management cybernetics.<ref>{{cite book|year=1968|author=Barry Clemson|title=Cybernetics: A new management tool|url=https://books.google.com/?id=VqQpICD5IXgC|isbn=9782881245183}}</ref> Patrick Hoverstadt wrote an introduction using real-life examples.<ref>{{cite book|author=Patrick Hoverstadt|title=The Fractal Organization:Creating sustainable organizations with the Viable System Model|year=2009|isbn=978-0-470-06056-8}}</ref>
== Organizational cybernetics ==
Organizational cybernetics (OC) is distinguished from management cybernetics. Both use many of the same terms but interpret them according to another philosophy of systems thinking. The full flowering of management cybernetics is represented in Beer's books<ref>[[Michael C. Jackson]] (1991), ''Systems Methodology for the Management Sciences''.</ref>
Organizational cybernetics studies organizational design, and the regulation and self-regulation of organizations from a [[systems theory]] perspective that also takes the social dimension into consideration. Extending the principles of [[autonomous agency theory]] (AAT), cultural agency theory (CAT) has been formulated for the generation of higher cybernetic orders.<ref>Yolles, M.I, Fink, G. (2014). Personality, pathology and mindsets: – Agency, Personality and Mindscapes, Kybernetes, 43(1)</ref> Researchers in economics, public administration and political science focus on the changes in institutions, organisation and mechanisms of social steering at various levels (sub-national, national, European, international) and in different sectors (including the private, semi-private and public sectors; the latter sector is emphasised).<ref name = "NSM">[http://www.ru.nl/imr/programmes/programmes/oc/ Organisational Cybernetics], Nijmegen School of Management, The Netherlands.</ref>
==See also== * [[Autonomous agency theory]] * [[Gregory Bateson]] * [[Institut für Unternehmenskybernetik]] * [[New cybernetics]] * [[Viable system theory]] * [[Warren McCulloch]]
==References== {{reflist|refs= <ref name=rosehead>Jonathan Rosenhead (2006) "IFORS' Operational Research Hall of Fame Stafford Beer", in ''International Transactions in Operational Research'' Vol 13, nr.6, pp. 577–578.</ref> }}
== Further reading == *Cwarel Isaf Institute (2002), Methods and Models, Retrieved 26 July 2007 from http://www.stafford-beer.com/en/fs_methmod.html * [[Stafford Beer]] (1959), ''Cybernetics and Management'', English University Press. 214pp. * Stafford Beer (1966), ''Decision and Control: The Meaning of Operational Research and Management Cybernetics'', 568 pages. * Stafford Beer (1972), ''Brain of the Firm: A Development in Management Cybernetics'', Herder and Herder. * Stafford Beer (1979), ''The Heart of Enterprise'', John Wiley, London and New York. * Stafford Beer (1985), ''Diagnosing the System for Organizations'', John Wiley, {{ISBN|0471906751}} * Raul Espejo (2006), "What is systemic thinking?", in: ''System Dynamics Review'', Vol 10, Issue 2-3, pp 199–212. * [[Michael C. Jackson]] (1991), ''Systems Methodology for the Management Sciences''. * Michael C. Jackson (2000), ''Systems Approaches to Management'', 465 p. * [[Richard F. Ericson]] (1969). [https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19710070289_1971070289.pdf ''Organizational cybernetics and human values'']. Program of Policy Studies in Science and Technology. Monograph. George Washington University. * [[Francis Heylighen]] (2001), "Cybernetics and Second-Order Cybernetics" in: R.A. Meyers (ed.), Encyclopedia of Physical Science & Technology (3rd ed.), (Academic Press, New York. * George E. Lasker and Aleksander Zgrzywa, (Eds.) (2003), ''Information Systems Research and Management Cybernetics'', 65 p. * A. Leonard (2002), "Stafford Beer: The Father of Management Cybernetics", in: ''Cybernetics & Human Knowing'', Volume 9, Numbers 3-4, 2002, pp. 133–136(4). * P.N. Rastogi (1979), ''Introduction to Social and Management Cybernetics'', New Delhi: Affiliated East West Press. * Lars Skyttner (2001), "Multiple perspectives of management cybernetics", in: ''General Systems Theory: Ideas & Applications'', p. 327-336. * [[Stuart A. Umpleby]] & Eric B. Dent (1999), [http://www.gwu.edu/~umpleby/recent_papers/1998_origins_purposes_several_traditions_systems_theory_cybernetic_1.htm "The origins and purposes of several traditions in systems theory and cybernetics"], in: ''Cybernetics & Systems'', Taylor & Francis * Wolfgang Winter & Manuela Thurm (2005), "Second-order cybernetics! In systemic management thinking?", in: ''Kybernetes'', Vol 34 Issue: 3/4 pp. 419–426.
==External links== *[http://www.cybsoc.org The Cybernetics Society] *[http://pespmc1.vub.ac.be/ASC/indexASC.html Web Dictionary of Cybernetics and Systems]
{{Cybernetics}}

[[Yolanda Hadid]] (divorced) |partner = Shiva Safai |relations = }} '''Mohamed Anwar Hadid''' ({{lang-ar|محمد حديد}}; born 6 November{{cite web | url = https://www.facebook.com/YolandaHFoster/posts/441702489264761 | publisher=Yolanda H. Foster verified [[Facebook]] page| date=6 November 2013 |title=Happy birthday Mohamed Hadid....| accessdate= 31 January 2016| archivedate= 31 January 2016 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160131190140/https://www.facebook.com/YolandaHFoster/posts/441702489264761 | deadurl=no}} 1948){{cite news |last=Jaffe |first=Harry |title=Unmasking the Mysterious Mohamed Hadid |url=http://www.harryjaffe.com/archive/unmasking-the-mysterious-mohamed-hadid |accessdate=20 December 2015 |work=[[Regardie's]]|date=1 March 1988 | archivedate=22 December 2015 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151222075934/http://www.harryjaffe.com/archive/unmasking-the-mysterious-mohamed-hadid | deadurl=no}} Note: Source gives birthplace as "Nazareth, Palestine". is a Jordanian-American real estate developer of [[Palestinian Americans|Palestinian origin]]. He is known for building luxury hotels and mansions, mainly in the [[Bel Air, Los Angeles|Bel Air]] neighborhood of the city of Los Angeles and [[Beverly Hills, California|Beverly Hills]] in [[Los Angeles County, California]]. ==Early life== Mohamed Anwar Hadid is a [[Palestinians|Palestinian]]{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/2014/09/face-launched-thousand-tweets-2014914121922159126.html|title=The face that launched a thousand tweets|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150110012437/http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/2014/09/face-launched-thousand-tweets-2014914121922159126.html|archivedate=2015-01-10|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://mondoweiss.net/2015/12/palestinian-details-refugee/|title=Not the only 'proud Palestinian' in the family–Gigi Hadid’s father details refugee history in Syria|date=31 December 2015|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-3373383/Gigi-Hadid-defends-Palestinian-roots-against-haters-photo-henna-tattooed-hands.html|title=Gigi Hadid defends her Palestinian roots with photo of henna tattoos|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160124023226/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-3373383/Gigi-Hadid-defends-Palestinian-roots-against-haters-photo-henna-tattooed-hands.html|archivedate=2016-01-24|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://blog.palestine-studies.org/2016/01/15/the-meaning-of-gigi-hadids-half-palestinian-post/|title=The Meaning of Gigi Hadid’s "Half-Palestinian"-Ness|first=Palestine|last=Square|date=15 January 2016|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160805035333/http://blog.palestine-studies.org/2016/01/15/the-meaning-of-gigi-hadids-half-palestinian-post/|archivedate=5 August 2016|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/life-style/art-and-culture/2016/01/18/10-world-famous-celebs-you-didn-t-know-were-of-Arab-origin-.html|title=10 world-famous celebs you didn’t know were of Arab origin|accessdate=10 September 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160907130055/http://english.alarabiya.net/en/life-style/art-and-culture/2016/01/18/10-world-famous-celebs-you-didn-t-know-were-of-Arab-origin-.html|archivedate=7 September 2016|df=}} born in [[Nazareth]] in November 1948, to a Muslim family. He is the son of Anwar Hadid (c. 1908 – 1979) and his wife Khairiah.{{cite news|title=Col. Homan, Veteran of 3 Wars, Dies |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/local/1989/05/14/col-homan-veteran-of-3-wars-dies/60bb00c7-ce3a-46b4-a2ea-d59099083b6f/ |date=14 May 1989 |accessdate=20 December 2015 |work=[[The Washington Post]] |archivedate=31 January 2016 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6exBbndjp?url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/local/1989/05/14/col-homan-veteran-of-3-wars-dies/60bb00c7-ce3a-46b4-a2ea-d59099083b6f/ |deadurl=no |df= }} Through his mother he claims descent from [[Zahir al-Umar|Daher Al Omer]], Prince of Nazareth and the Sheik of Galilee.{{cite web|last1=Tully|first1=Shawn|last2=Blank|first2=J. B.|title=The Big Moneymen of Palestine Inc.|url=http://archive.fortune.com/magazines/fortune/fortune_archive/1989/07/31/72291/index.htm|work=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]|accessdate=17 June 2016|language=English|date=31 July 1989|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222160613/http://archive.fortune.com/magazines/fortune/fortune_archive/1989/07/31/72291/index.htm|archivedate=22 December 2015|df=}}{{cite web|title=The Radar People Surreal Estate Developer|url=http://digital.modernluxury.com/article/The+Radar+People/453793/0/article.html|website=ANGE – Angelo|publisher=Modern Luxury|accessdate=17 June 2016|language=English|date=August 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160622064637/http://digital.modernluxury.com/article/The%2BRadar%2BPeople/453793/0/article.html|archivedate=22 June 2016|df=}} Hadid has two brothers and five sisters. His father, Anwar Hadid studied at a [[Jerusalem]] teachers' college and attended a university{{which|date=December 2015}} in [[Syria]] to study law, before working in land settlement for the British authorities and teaching English at a teachers' college in [[Mandatory Palestine]]. In 1948, he moved to Syria and joined the [[United States Information Agency]] and the ''[[Voice of America]]''. He and his family lived in [[Damascus]], [[Tunisia]], and [[Greece]] before moving to [[Washington D.C.]], as Anwar had a job at the VOA headquarters there, when Mohamed was 14, and spent the rest of his career there with VOA and USIA as a writer, editor and translator.{{cite news|last1=Warren Walsh |first1=Sharon |first2=David S. |last2=Hilzenrath |title=Who is Mohamed Hadid? |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/business/1989/04/24/who-is-mohamed-hadid/4b6ff72a-ec4e-454c-b282-d4d4b5405ea5/ |accessdate=20 December 2015 |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=24 April 1989 |archivedate=31 January 2016 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6exBr14b7?url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/business/1989/04/24/who-is-mohamed-hadid/4b6ff72a-ec4e-454c-b282-d4d4b5405ea5/ |deadurl=no |df= }} Hadid attended [[North Carolina State University]] and the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]. ==Career== Among his early ventures was a company that exported equipment to the Middle East.{{cite news|work=[[The Washington Post]]|title=Who is Mohamed Hadid?|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/business/1989/04/24/who-is-mohamed-hadid/4b6ff72a-ec4e-454c-b282-d4d4b5405ea5/|accessdate=26 July 2017|first1=Sharon Warren|last1=Walsh|first2=David S.|last2=Hilzenrath|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6exBr14b7?url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/business/1989/04/24/who-is-mohamed-hadid/4b6ff72a-ec4e-454c-b282-d4d4b5405ea5/|archivedate=31 January 2016|df=}} He started his career restoring and reselling classic cars in the [[Georgetown (Washington, D.C.)|Georgetown]] neighborhood of [[Washington, D.C.]], before moving to Greece where he opened a nightclub on an island, and with the profits, started developing real estate back in the United States. In the 1980s, much of his financial clout came from the [[SAAR Foundation]], a Herndon-based foundation with Saudi roots. The foundation was a 50-50 partner in many of Hadid's ventures. In the late 1980s, he faced at least 30 lawsuits from creditors and banks claiming he had not fulfilled various financial obligations.{{cite news|work=The Washington Post|title=Hard Times for Developer Mohamed Hadid|url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/business/1989/11/20/hard-times-for-developer-mohamed-hadid/f853c2e4-9bbb-4a28-bf25-e9a8bc6ae4d5/|accessdate=26 July 2017|first= Jacqueline L. |last=Salmon}} He paid $150 million for the Ritz-Carlton hotels in Washington and New York. He also converted a Houston hotel into a Ritz-Carlton Hotel and developed a Ritz-Carlton resort in Scottsdale, Arizona. He outmaneuvered Donald Trump, paid $42.9 million for several choice parcels in Aspen and announced plans for a 292-room Ritz resort. In 1992, a settlement was reached in a lawsuit by Riggs Bank against Columbia First Bank Chairman Melvin Lenkin, a Hadid partner in a Washington, D.C., construction project that involved a loan on which Hadid defaulted. Following the settlement Hadid closed his local office, lost his McLean home to foreclosure, and left the Washington area.{{cite news|title=Riggs Settlement with Lenkin Gives it Cash, Pledge, Building|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/business/1992/08/04/riggs-settlement-with-lenkin-gives-it-cash-pledge-building/57c6b062-d9a4-473f-abec-aaa3a4037467/| first=David S. |last=Hilzenrath |date= August 4, 1992|accessdate=August 22, 2017|work=[[The Washington Post]]}} He developed Le Belvedere, a mansion in [[Bel Air, Los Angeles|Bel Air]], Los Angeles,{{cite news|last1=Halderman|first1=Peter|title=In Los Angeles, a Nimby Battle Pits Millionaires vs. Billionaires|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/07/style/in-los-angeles-a-nimby-battle-pits-millionaires-vs-billionaires.html?_r=0|accessdate=24 January 2016|work=The New York Times|date=December 5, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504030358/http://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/07/style/in-los-angeles-a-nimby-battle-pits-millionaires-vs-billionaires.html?_r=0|archivedate=4 May 2015|df=}} that sold for $50 million in 2010. In 2012, he developed The Crescent Palace, a 48,000-square-foot home on an acre plot next door to the [[Beverly Hills Hotel]], which he listed for sale at $58 million. Shortly after Hadid received approval for the construction of a mansion in Bel Air, the Bel Air Homeowners Alliance, chaired by [[Fred Rosen (businessman)|Fred Rosen]], was formed to oppose it. In January 2015, [[Nancy Walton Laurie]], an heiress to the [[Walmart]] fortune and a Bel Air resident, filed a lawsuit through her company, LW Partnership, against Hadid.{{cite news|first=Matt |last=Lopez |url=http://bhcourier.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/012315Fissue.pdf |title=Wal-Mart Heiress Seeks Damages From Bel Air's 901 Strada Vecchia |work=[[The Beverly Hills Courier]] |location=California |date=23 January 2015 |pages=1, 11 |archivedate=31 January 2016 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6exCFY45s?url=http://bhcourier.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/012315Fissue.pdf |deadurl=no |df= }} Laurie accused Hadid of damaging the roots of a [[eucalyptus tree]] on her property with a retaining wall he built next to her house. In December 2015, the [[Los Angeles City Council|Los Angeles city council]] voted to pursue criminal charges over a claim that Hadid violated local [[zoning]] laws. The council alleged he built his house contrary to multiple planning orders and made it twice the permitted size.{{cite news|last1=Tait|first1=Robert|title=Bad airs in Bel-Air over house dubbed 'the starship enterprise'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/12059349/Bad-airs-in-Bel-Air-over-house-dubbed-the-starship-enterprise.html|accessdate=20 December 2015|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=19 December 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151219184212/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/12059349/Bad-airs-in-Bel-Air-over-house-dubbed-the-starship-enterprise.html|archivedate=19 December 2015|df=}}{{cite news|last1=Lopez|first1=Matt|title=Did 901 Strada Vecchia In Bel-Air Violate Stop Work Order With Weekend Construction Work?|url=http://bhcourier.com/did-901-strada-vecchia-in-bel-air-violate-stop-work-order-with-weekend-construction-work/|accessdate=20 December 2015|work=The Beverly Hills Courier| location= California|date=1 December 2014 | archivedate= 13 August 2015 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150813063312/http://bhcourier.com/did-901-strada-vecchia-in-bel-air-violate-stop-work-order-with-weekend-construction-work/ | deadurl=no}} In May 2017, Hadid pleaded no contest to misdemeanor charges stemming from mansion-construction issues for which he did not receive city approval, and was sentenced that July to community service and fines.{{cite news|work=Los Angeles Times|title=Bel-Air mega-mansion developer Mohamed Hadid sentenced with community service, fines|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-hadid-sentencing-20170720-story.html|accessdate=27 July 2017|first1=Emily Alpert|last1=Reyes|first2=Dakota|last2=Smith|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170721062333/http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-hadid-sentencing-20170720-story.html|archivedate=21 July 2017|df=}}{{cite news|first=Emily Alpert|last=Reyes|title=Celebrity developer pleads no contest to Bel-Air mega-mansion charges. But what happens to the 30,000-square-foot estate?|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-bel-air-building-20170530-htmlstory.html|accessdate=27 July 2017|work=Los Angeles Times|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170710040002/http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-bel-air-building-20170530-htmlstory.html|archivedate=10 July 2017|df=}} In July 2017, he was sentenced to 200 hours of community service, summoned to return $14,191 to the City of Los Angeles in damages, and fined $3,000.{{cite news|last1=Lopez|first1=Matt|title=Hadid Fined, Sentenced To Community Service – But No Jail Time – Over Bel-Air Mansion|url=http://bhcourier.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/072117Fissue.pdf|accessdate=July 22, 2017|work=The Beverly Hills Courier|date=July 21, 2017|pages=1; 19}} He was also given a three-year probation period to ensure the property would comply with existing regulations, or he would face a 180-day jail sentence. ==Athletic career== Hadid competed in the demonstration sport of [[Speed skiing at the 1992 Winter Olympics|speed skiing]] at the [[1992 Winter Olympics]], representing [[Jordan]]. He was 43 years old at the time. Hadid was encouraged to participate by his friend, [[Austria]]n Olympic skier [[Franz Weber (skier)|Franz Weber]]. Hadid was the only member of the Jordanian delegation, and remains the only person to have represented Jordan in the [[Winter Olympics]].{{cite web|last1=Walsh|first1=Sharon|title=Snow Folling: Mo Knows Skiing|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/business/1991/12/21/snow-fooling-mo-knows-skiing/53a6fc0f-4e64-4bfc-9282-c294d55fc1e2/|website=The Washington Post|accessdate=26 April 2017|language=English|date=21 December 1991|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170519175709/https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/business/1991/12/21/snow-fooling-mo-knows-skiing/53a6fc0f-4e64-4bfc-9282-c294d55fc1e2/|archivedate=19 May 2017|df=}}{{cite web|last1=Rosenfeld|first1=Laura|title=You're Not Going to Believe Which Bravoleb Was an Olympian|url=http://www.bravotv.com/the-daily-dish/mohamed-hadid-competed-in-1992-olympics-albertville-france|website=Bravo TV Official Site|accessdate=26 April 2017|language=English|date=5 August 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170427192434/http://www.bravotv.com/the-daily-dish/mohamed-hadid-competed-in-1992-olympics-albertville-france|archivedate=27 April 2017|df=}} ==Television appearances== Hadid has appeared on the TV show ''[[The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills]]'', as the ex-husband of [[Yolanda Hadid]].{{cite news|last1=Brennan|first1=Morgan|title=Celebrity Developer Mohamed Hadid Asking $58 Million For Crescent Palace|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/morganbrennan/2012/06/28/celebrity-developer-asking-58-million-for-his-most-opulent-mansion-yet/|accessdate=20 December 2015|work=[[Forbes]]|date=28 June 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222111359/http://www.forbes.com/sites/morganbrennan/2012/06/28/celebrity-developer-asking-58-million-for-his-most-opulent-mansion-yet/|archivedate=22 December 2015|df=}} He has also appeared on ''[[Shahs of Sunset]]''., and Second Wives Club on E! with his fiancée Shiva Safai in 2017{{Cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2017/05/04/second-wives-club-star-shiva-safai-talks-33-year-age-gap-with-her-man-dishes-on-gigi-and-bella-hadid.html|title='Second Wives Club' star Shiva Safai talks 33-year age gap with her man, dishes on Gigi and Bella Hadid|last=Nolasco|first=Stephanie|date=2017-05-04|work=Fox News|access-date=2018-06-23|language=en-US}}. ==Personal life== [[File:AnnaSui-FW17RTW-Hadids-BW.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Two of Hadid's daughters, models [[Bella Hadid|Bella]] and [[Gigi Hadid]]]] His first wife was Mary Butler, with whom he had two daughters, Alana Hadid and Marielle Hadid. He and Butler ended their marriage in 1992.{{cite news|last1=Romano|first1=Lois|title=The reliable source|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1992/05/21/the-reliable-source/23772a57-67ea-42d7-8e2b-e7aaf8a9b99c/|accessdate=23 December 2015|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=21 May 1992|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151225044643/https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1992/05/21/the-reliable-source/23772a57-67ea-42d7-8e2b-e7aaf8a9b99c/|archivedate=25 December 2015|df=}}{{cite news|last1=Watson|first1=Sheridan|title=The Foster-Hadids Are The Best Family On Earth|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/sheridanwatson/the-foster-hadids-are-the-best-family-on-earth#.cjPJkQ93W|accessdate=23 December 2015|work=[[BuzzFeed]]|date=14 October 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160331163719/http://www.buzzfeed.com/sheridanwatson/the-foster-hadids-are-the-best-family-on-earth#.cjPJkQ93W|archivedate=31 March 2016|df=}} From 1994 until their divorce in 2000, he was married to the Dutch model [[Yolanda Hadid]], née Van den Herik.{{cite news|last1=Corriston|first1=Michele|title=Yolanda Drops 'Foster' as Divorce Proceeds, Takes Ex-Husband's Name Again|url=http://www.people.com/article/why-yolanda-foster-goes-by-hadid-now|accessdate=18 February 2016|work=People|date=17 February 2016| archivedate= 18 February 2016| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160218093942/http://www.people.com/article/why-yolanda-foster-goes-by-hadid-now}} They had three children, who all became models: [[Gigi Hadid|Gigi]] (born 1995), [[Bella Hadid|Bella]] (born 1996), and [[Anwar Hadid|Anwar]] (born 1999).{{cite news|last1=Frank|first1=Julia|title=Gigi and Bella Hadid's younger brother Anwar is a model too|url=http://www.vogue.com.au/fashion/news/gigi+and+bella+hadids+younger+brother+anwar+is+a+model+too,37492|accessdate=2 January 2016|work=[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]|date=25 September 2015|quote=16-year-old Anwar Hadid...|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160301171735/http://www.vogue.com.au/fashion/news/gigi%2Band%2Bbella%2Bhadids%2Byounger%2Bbrother%2Banwar%2Bis%2Ba%2Bmodel%2Btoo%2C37492|archivedate=1 March 2016|df=}} As of 2014, Hadid is engaged to Shiva Safai, a model and businesswoman. She was born in Iran and raised in Norway, and at age 19, moved to Los Angeles with her family.{{cite news|title=Interview and Photoshoot with Shiva Safai |url=http://www.naludamagazine.com/interview-and-photoshoot-with-shiva-safai/ |accessdate=23 December 2015 |publisher=NaludaMagazine.com |date=1 January 2015 |archivedate=31 January 2016 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6exCP3ad7?url=http://www.naludamagazine.com/interview-and-photoshoot-with-shiva-safai/ |deadurl=no |df= }} Hadid is a dual Jordanian-American citizen. He does not consider himself a devout Muslim, but has [[Teetotalism|never drunk alcohol]], although he does have a 5,000-bottle wine cellar, including some from his own Beverly Hills winery.{{cite news|last1=Farameh |first1=Patrice |title=Hadid’s Modern Masterpiece: Mohamed Hadid |url=http://hauteliving.com/2008/07/hadids-modern-masterpiece/3038/ |accessdate=20 December 2015 |work=[[Haute Living]] |date=1 July 2008 |quote=Even though he has never indulged in alcohol in his life, his 5,000-bottle wine cellar is filled with the best French and Californian wines. Not only does his collection consist of a diverse range of premium wines from local vineyards such as Summerland Winery, but it also includes bottles from his very own winery in Beverly Hills. |archivedate=31 January 2016 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6exBwHf4u?url=http://hauteliving.com/2008/07/hadids-modern-masterpiece/3038/ |deadurl=no |df= }} In 2017, his fiancée, Shiva Safai, who is 33 years his junior, began to appear in [[E!]] reality show, ''[[Second Wives Club]]''.{{cite web|title=Shiva Safai from Second Wives Club: Meet the Cast|url=http://www.eonline.com/shows/second_wives_club/photos/20470/second-wives-club-meet-the-cast/750857|publisher=[[E! News]]|accessdate=25 April 2017|language=English|date=n.d.| archivedate= 30 March 2017| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170330212752/http://www.eonline.com/shows/second_wives_club/photos/20470/second-wives-club-meet-the-cast/750857|deadurl=no}}{{cite web|last1=Nolasco|first1=Stephanie|title='Second Wives Club' star Shiva Safai talks 33-year age gap with her man, dishes on Gigi and Bella Hadid|url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2017/05/04/second-wives-club-star-shiva-safai-talks-33-year-age-gap-with-her-man-dishes-on-gigi-and-bella-hadid.html|publisher=[[Fox News]]|accessdate=25 May 2017|language=English|date=4 May 2017| archivedate= 15 June 2017| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170615042156/http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2017/05/04/second-wives-club-star-shiva-safai-talks-33-year-age-gap-with-her-man-dishes-on-gigi-and-bella-hadid.html| deadurl=no}} {{-}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Official website|http://www.mohamedhadid.com/}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hadid, Mohamed}} [[Category:1948 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Nazareth]] [[Category:People from Bel Air, Los Angeles]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Los Angeles]] [[Category:Jordanian people of Palestinian descent]] [[Category:American people of Palestinian descent]] [[Category:Jordanian businesspeople]] [[Category:American real estate businesspeople]] [[Category:Jordanian sportsmen]] [[Category:Jordanian Muslims]] [[Category:American Muslims]] [[Category:Jordanian emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Hadid family|Mohamed]]

{{Infobox person |name = Philippe Crébassa |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = |birth_place = |death_date = |death_place = |body_discovered = |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = [[France]] |nationality = [[France|French]] |ethnicity = |citizenship = |other_names = |known_for = President of [[Toulouse-Blagnac Airport]] |education = [[Aerospace engineer]], [[Economist]] |alma_mater = [[École Polytechnique]]
[[École nationale de l'aviation civile]]
[[Toulouse School of Economics]] |employer = [[Toulouse-Blagnac Airport]] |occupation = President of [[Toulouse-Blagnac Airport]] |years_active = |home_town = |title = |salary = |networth = |height = |weight = |term = |predecessor = [[Jean-Michel Vernhes]] |successor = |party = |opponents = |boards = |religion = |spouse = |partner = |children = |parents = |relations = |callsign = |signature = |website = |footnotes = }} '''Philippe Crébassa''' is a [[France|French]] [[public servant]] who is the current President of the [[Toulouse-Blagnac Airport]].{{fr}} [https://www.latribune.fr/entreprises-finance/services/transport-logistique/philippe-crebassa-enac-en-passe-de-diriger-l-aeroport-de-toulouse-780031.html Philippe Crébassa (ENAC) en passe de diriger l'aéroport de Toulouse] He succeeded Jean-Michel Vernhes in that position. == Biography == Crébassa graduated from [[École Polytechnique]], the [[École nationale de l'aviation civile]], and the [[Toulouse School of Economics]].{{fr}} [https://www.letudiant.fr/educpros/nominations/philippe-crebassa-administrateur-provisoire-de-l-enac.html Philippe Crebassa, administrateur provisoire de l'Enac] He started his career as an economist for the [[Directorate General for Civil Aviation (France)|Directorate General for Civil Aviation]] in 1992. Within the Directorate, he became Head of Infrastructure, Communication, and Navigation in 1997; Head of Development, Air Traffic Control Training in 2002; and Head of Innovation, En Route Air Traffic Control in 2005. He joined [[Egis Group|Egis avia]] in 2007 as Business Development Manager for Europe, India, and southeast Asia. In 2009, he was made Chief Strategy Officer, and in 2011, he became the Chief Operating Officer.[https://www.bloomberg.com/profiles/people/17292746-philippe-crebassa Philippe Crebassa] From 2013 to 2018, he was Vice-President of the [[École nationale de l'aviation civile]].[http://www.halldale.com/philippe-crebassa-christian-commissaire#.WxRH0Irfuf0 Philippe Crebassa & Christian Commissaire] In June 2018, he became the CEO of the [[Toulouse-Blagnac Airport]].{{fr}}[http://www.aeromorning.com/blog/president-du-directoire-de-laeroport-de-toulouse-blagnac/ Président du Directoire de l’Aéroport de Toulouse-Blagnac] == References == {{Reflist|2}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Crebassa, Philippe}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:French businesspeople]] [[Category:École Polytechnique alumni]] [[Category:École nationale de l'aviation civile alumni]] [[Category:Aviation in France]] [[Category:French aerospace engineers]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Pino Tovaglia | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth-date|3 December 1923}} | birth_place =[[Milan]], Italy | birth_name = | death_date = {{Death-date and age|30 November 1977|3 December 1923}} | death_place = Milan, Italy | occupation = Graphic designer }}'''Pino Tovaglia''' (3 December 1923 - 30 November 1977) was an Italian graphic designer. He is regarded as one of the major exponents of the [[International Typographic Style|Swiss Style]] in Italy.<ref name="bio" />
Born in [[Milan]], Tovaglia was active in the field of graphic design since his youth, first as an assistant of [[Carlo Carrà]], and then as a collaborator of [[Marco Zanuso]], [[Giò Ponti]], and the Castiglioni brothers. From 1946 he was professor of graphic design in several art schools of Milan.<ref name="Vogue">{{cite news|last1=Fabia Di Drusco|title=Focus su Pino Tovaglia|url=http://www.vogue.it/uomo-vogue/news/2012/04/pino-tovaglia-triennale|accessdate=14 October 2016|work=[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]|date=12 April 2012}}</ref>
In 1954 Tovaglia won the National Prize of Advertising thanks to an advertisement series made for [[Finmeccanica]]. In 1956 he founded the NCPT Studio together with Giulio Confalonieri, Ilio Negri and Michele Provinciali. In 1958 he won the Golden Palm at the [[Cannes Lions International Advertising Festival]].<ref name="bio">Giorgio Fioravanti. "Pino Tovaglia". ''Il dizionario del grafico''. Bologna, Zanichelli, 1993.{{ISBN|88-08-14116-0}}. p. 468.</ref>
From 1967 to 1970 Tovaglia was art director of [[Pirelli]], and in the same period he realized famous posters such as ''Italia da salvare'' (1967), ''Cinturato Pirelli'' (1967) and ''Brandy Stock'' (1970). In 1972 he realized the restyling of the [[Alfa Romeo]] logo, while in 1975 he designed the symbol of the [[Lombardy Region]] in collaboration with [[Bruno Munari]], [[Bob Noorda]] and Roberto Sambonet.<ref name="bio"/>
A member of [[Alliance Graphique Internationale]], in 1998 he was awarded a posthumous [[Compasso d'Oro]] for his career. A collection consisting in over 13,000 pieces is kept at the CSAC (Study Center and Archives of Communication) of the [[University of Parma]], and several of his works are part of the permanent collection at [[MoMa]], New York.<ref name="Vogue"/>
== Further reading ==
* Massimo Pitis. ''Pino Tovaglia: The Rule That Corrects Emotion''. Corraini, 2005. {{ISBN|978-88-757-0082-9}}.
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Tovaglia, Pino}} [[Category:1923 births]] [[Category:1977 deaths]] [[Category:People from Milan]] [[Category:Italian graphic designers]] [[Category:Advertising people]]
