revision.text:
[[Image:PerceptualMap3.png|thumb|right|Perceptual map of competing products with ideal vectors]] '''Preference regression''' is a statistical technique used by marketers to determine consumers’ [[Preference|preferred]] core benefits. It usually supplements [[positioning (marketing)|product positioning]] techniques like [[multi dimensional scaling (in marketing)|multi dimensional scaling]] or [[factor analysis]] and is used to create ideal vectors on [[perceptual mapping|perceptual maps]].
==Application== Starting with raw data from surveys, researchers apply positioning techniques to determine important dimensions and plot the position of competing [[product (business)|products]] on these dimensions. Next they [[regression analysis|regress]] the survey data against the dimensions. The independent variables are the data collected in the survey. The dependent variable is the preference datum. Like all regression methods, the computer fits weights to best predict data. The resultant regression line is referred to as an ideal vector because the slope of the vector is the ratio of the preferences for the two dimensions.
If all the data is used in the regression, the program will derive a single equation and hence a single ideal vector. This tends to be a blunt instrument so researchers refine the process with [[cluster analysis (in marketing)|cluster analysis]]. This creates clusters that reflect [[market segment]]s. Separate preference regressions are then done on the data within each segment. This provides an ideal vector for each segment.
==Alternative methods== [[Self-stated importance method]] is an alternative method in which direct survey data is used to determine the weightings rather than statistical imputations. A third method is [[conjoint analysis (marketing)|conjoint analysis]] in which an additive method is used.
==See also== * [[Marketing]] * [[Product management]] * [[Positioning (marketing)]] * [[Marketing research]] * [[Perceptual mapping]] * [[Multidimensional scaling]] * [[Factor analysis]] * [[Linear discriminant analysis#Marketing]] * [[Preference-rank translation]]
==References==
*{{Cite book | last1 = Park | first1 = S. '''Raam Jethmal Punjabi''' ([[Punjabi language|Punjabi]]: ਰਾਮ ਪੰਜਾਬੀ) is an [[Indian Indonesian]] media magnate and president of [[Cinema of Indonesia#1990s|Multivision Plus]].<ref name="asiaimage1"/> In 2001, due to his production of [[soap opera]]s, he was referred to as "Indonesia's own soap king".<ref name="dailynews1"/>
==Early life== He was born in [[Surabaya]], [[East Java]] to parents of [[Indian Indonesian|Indian]] ([[Sindhi people|Sindhi]]) descent.<ref>[http://www.indoindians.com/rampunjabi.htm "King of Soap Opera"] - Indonesian Indians</ref> His nephew is [[Manoj Punjabi]].<ref name="TH">{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-opinion/sindhi-kings-of-indonesian-entertainment/article5054226.ece |title=Sindhi kings of Indonesian entertainment |date=24 August 2013 |accessdate=26 October 2015 |first=Pallavi |last=Aiyar |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140620123008/http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-opinion/sindhi-kings-of-indonesian-entertainment/article5054226.ece |archivedate=June 20, 2014 }}</ref>
==Career==

{{Infobox person | name = Rachel Rose | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1986}} | residence = | nationality = United States | education = B.A. [[Yale University]]
M.A. [[Courtauld Institute of Art]]
M.F.A. [[Columbia University]]. | occupation = Artist | known_for = | ethnicity = | religion = | networth = | children = | spouse = | parents = Diana Calthorpe Rose
[[Jonathan F. P. Rose]] | family = [[Peter Calthorpe]] (uncle)
[[Frederick P. Rose]] (grandfather) | website = }} '''Rachel Rose''' (born 1986) is an American [[visual artist]] known for her video installations that merge moving images and sound within nuanced environments connecting them to broader but related subject matter.[http://whitney.org/Exhibitions/RachelRose Whitney Museum of Modern Art: "RACHEL ROSE: EVERYTHING AND MORE OCT 30, 2015–FEB 7, 2016"] retrieved May 28, 2016[http://bombmagazine.org/article/8919825/rachel-rose Bomb Magazine: "Rachel Rose" by Aily Nash][http://www.wmagazine.com/culture/art-and-design/2015/11/rachel-rose-whitney-museum/photos/ W Magazine: "Rachel Rose: Art Star – The artist goes interstellar with her new Whitney exhibition" by Fan Zhong] November 3, 2015[http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2015/11/30/seeing-stars-art-andrea-k-scott The New Yorker: "Seeing Stars – A young New Yorker brings her space odyssey to the Whitney" BY ANDREA K. SCOTT] November 30, 2015 Rose has presented solo exhibits at the Serpentine Galleries and the Whitney Museum of Art.{{cite web| url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/abinlot/2015/11/11/rachel-rose-jared-madere-take-center-stage-at-the-whitney-art-party/#70f8001f323a| title=Rachel Rose, Jared Madere Take Center Stage At The Whitney Art Party| author=Ann Binlot| date=November 11, 2015| publisher=Forbes| access-date=July 14, 2015}}{{cite web| url=http://moussemagazine.it/rachel-rose-jimmie-durham-serpentine/| title=Rachel Rose "Palisades" at Serpentine Sackler Gallery| publisher=Mousse Magazine| access-date=July 14, 2016}} ==Early life and education== Rose is the daughter of Diana (née Calthorpe) and [[Jonathan F. P. Rose]].[https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/18/arts/design/rachel-rose-driven-by-distraction-heads-to-the-whitney.html?_r=0 New York Times: "Rachel Rose, Driven by Distraction, Heads to the Whitney" By BLAKE GOPNIK] October 16, 2015 | ''She tidily leaves out one detail: His “planning” comes in the context of a vast real estate empire. Jonathan F. P. Rose, who develops sustainable housing, is the scion of the same Rose clan whose name is on Manhattan’s Rose Center for Earth and Space and the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Rose Cinemas.)''[https://www.nytimes.com/2004/04/11/nyregion/in-person-developer-with-eye-to-profits-for-society.html IN PERSON; Developer With Eye To Profits For Society" By TINA KELLEY] April 11, 2004 |''In 2002 he and his wife, Diana Calthorpe Rose, formed the Garrison Institute at a former Capuchin monastery in Garrison..''[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4ysPL1vn5dQ BuildingNY: "The Life of Jonathan F. P. Rose"] Minute 28:58 – October 10, 2012 | ''My wife is Diana Rose; my daughters are Rachel Rose and Ariel Flores Zurofsky'' Her father is an urban planner with a focus on sustainable housing, and her uncle is architect [[Peter Calthorpe]].[http://uli.org/nichols-prize-winners/2006-jc-nichols-prize-winner-peter-calthorpe/ Urban Land Institute: "C. Nichols Prize Winner—Peter Calthorpe" by Leigh Franke] August 3, 2006 |''Rose also has a personal relationship with Calthorpe — he is married to Calthorpe’s sister.'' She grew up on a farm in upstate New York. She earned a B.A. in art from [[Yale University]]; a M.A. in art history from the [[Courtauld Institute of Art]]; and a M.F.A. from [[Columbia University]]. She entered graduate school as an abstract painter where she studied under [[Rirkrit Tiravanija]]. ==Work== Rose produces video installations juxtaposing images and sounds demonstrating that life is complex and intricate. Whitney curator Christopher Y. Lew approved of “how she was able to gather such a mix of images, and of content as well, and weave it into a unique narrative. She pulled some kind of order out of our whirlpool of information, without ever denying the flood". Rose's videos consist of original footage and found material combined to depict an autonomous perspective using language and technology.{{cite web| url=http://www.flashartonline.com/article/it-looked-like-a-universe/| title=It Looked Like a Universe| date=October 2015| publisher=Flash Art| access-date=July 15, 2016}} Her experiential pieces work to convey sensorial aspects of ideas by manipulating sound and image. Her imagery depicts "humanity's shard current anxieties and their multi-layered interconnectivity" as well as humanities' relationship to the natural world, advancing technology, mortality, and history. Each video is driven by an intense period of research centered on a subject, theory or belief. The [[Taipei Fine Arts Museum|Taipei]] Biennial exhibition featured Rose's 2013 video, ''Sitting Feeding Sleeping'',{{cite web| url=http://www.artinamericamagazine.com/reviews/taipei-biennial-2014/| title=Taipei Biennial 2014| author=Kevin McGarry| date=December 26, 2014| publisher=Art in America| access-date=July 15, 2016}} which debuted at the artist's graduate thesis exhibition.{{cite web| url=http://www.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/1070745/reel-to-real-rachel-roses-trippy-videos-have-painterly-roots| title=Reel to Real: Rachel Rose's Trippy Videos Have Painterly Roots| author=Wendy Vogel| date=January 3, 2015| publisher=Blouin Art Info| access-date=July 15, 2016}} Rose's 2014 video ''Palisades in Palisades'' focused on the human relationship with the natural world and was shot in [[Palisades Interstate Park]] in New Jersey. Her video ''A Minute Ago'' focuses on [[Philip Johnson]]'s [[Glass House]]{{cite web| url=http://www.widewalls.ch/artist-rachel-rose-whitney-museum/| title=Why has emerging artist Rachel Rose captivated the entire art world| author=Amy Lin| publisher=WideWalls| access-date=July 15, 2016}} and was shown in Rose's exhibition, ''Palisades'', at the [[Serpentine Galleries|Serpentine Gallery]] in London in 2015. ''Palisades'' featured both ''A Minute Ago'' and ''Palisades in Palisades''. In October 2015, Rose presented ''Everything and More'', a solo show at the [[Whitney Museum of American Art]].{{cite web| url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2015/oct/26/rachel-rose-artist-gravity-space-whitney-museum| title=Rachel Rose: artist sets out on Gravity-inspired space odyssey| author=Charlotte Burns| date=October 26, 2015| publisher=The Guardian| access-date=July 14, 2016}} Rose projected the video on a semi-transparent screen and covered the windows of the gallery's black box with opaque scrim to achieve an out-of-body feel. ''Everything and More'' was inspired by [[David Wolf (astronaut)|David Wolf's]] experience of a space walk. The 11 minute and 30 second film was partially shot in a neutral buoyancy pool at the [[University of Maryland, College Park|University of Maryland]].{{cite web| url=http://www.artinamericamagazine.com/exhibitions/rachel-rose/| title=Rachel Rose| publisher=Art in America| access-date=July 14, 2016}} Rose participated in the 2017 Venice Biennale, ''Viva Arte Viva''.{{Cite web|url=http://www.labiennale.org/en/art/exhibition/artists/index.html|title=La Biennale di Venezia - Artists|website=www.labiennale.org|access-date=2017-02-22|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170629160716/http://www.labiennale.org/en/art/exhibition/artists/index.html|archivedate=2017-06-29|df=}} ==Exhibitions== * ''Uncanny Valleys'', Electronic Arts Intermix, New York (2013) *''Geographies of Contamination'', David Roberts Art Foundation, London (2013)[http://www.serpentinegalleries.org/exhibitions-events/rachel-rose-palisades Serpentine Galleries: "Rachel Rose: Palisades"] retrieved May 28, 2016 *''Chance Motives'', Sculpture Center, New York (2013) *''The Great Acceleration'', Taipei Biennial, Taipei (2014) *''Phantom Limbs,'' Pilar Corrias Gallery, London (2014) *''A Minute Ago'', High Art, Paris (2014) * ''Welt am Draht'' at Julia Stoschek Collection, Berlin{{cite web| url=http://www.pilarcorrias.com/news/welt-am-draht-at-julia-stoschek-collection-berlin/ | title="Welt am Draht" at Julia Stoschek Collection - Berlin | publisher=Pilar Corrias | access-date=12 July 2016}} *''Palisades'' at the [[Serpentine Galleries]] (2015) *''Co-workers'' at the Musee D'Art Moderne (2015){{cite web| url=http://www.ofluxo.net/co-workers-the-network-as-artist-beyond-disaster/| title=Co-Workers - The Network as Artist| publisher=OFluxo| access-date=July 15, 2016}} *''Everything and More'' at The [[Whitney Museum of American Art]] (2015) *''Interiors'' at [[Castello di Rivoli]] (2015); *''Visitors'', [[Governor's Island]], New York (2015){{cite web| url=http://artdaily.com/news/81809/First-solo-show-in-London-by-Rachel-Rose-opens-at-the-Serpentine-Sackler-Gallery#.V3LfRJMrIcg | title=First solo show in London by Rachel Rose opens at the Serpentine Sackler Gallery | publisher=Art Daily | access-date=12 July 2016}} *''Cloud Cover'', [[Center for Curatorial Studies and Art in Contemporary Culture|CCS Hessel Museum of Contemporary Art]], Annandale-on-Hudson, New York (2015) *''The Importance of Being a (Moving) Image'', [[National Gallery in Prague|National Gallery]], Prague (2015) *''The Infinite Mix'' at [[Hayward Gallery]] (2016){{cite web| url=https://www.standard.co.uk/goingout/arts/the-infinite-mix-review-this-incendiary-mix-of-sound-and-vision-is-a-contender-for-show-of-the-year-a3337576.html| title=The Infinite Mix| date=September 6, 2016| author=Ben Luke| publisher=Standard| access-date=January 3, 2017}} * ''Lake Valley'' at Pilar Corrias (2016){{cite web| date=20 September 2016 | title=Rachel Rose| url=https://frieze.com/article/rachel-rose| first=Ellen | last=Mara de Wachter| publisher=Frieze| accessdate=11 January 2017}} * ''Okayama Art Summit'' in Japan (2016){{cite web | date=9 August 2016 | title=Liam Gillick Is Artistic Director of Okayama Art Summit's First Edition | url=https://news.artnet.com/exhibitions/liam-gillick-artistic-director-first-okayama-art-summit-596957| first=Amah-Rose | last=Abrams | publisher=ArtNet News | accessdate=11 January 2017 }} *''Rachel Rose'' at [[Aspen Art Museum]] (2016){{cite web|url=http://www.pilarcorrias.com/news/rachel-rose-at-aspen-art-museum/| title=Rachel Rose at Aspen Art Museum| publisher=Pilar Corrias| accessdate=August 3, 2016}} *''Life Itself'' at Moderna Museet (2016){{cite web| url=http://www.modernamuseet.se/stockholm/en/exhibitions/life-itself/| title=Life Itself| publisher=Moderna Museet| accessdate=August 3, 2016}} *''Biennale'', Venice (2017) *''Enfance'' at [[Palais de Tokyo]], Paris (2018) *''Rachel Rose: Wil-o-Wisp/The Future Fields Commission'' at [[Philadelphia Museum of Art]] (2018)[http://www.philamuseum.org/exhibitions/877.html "Rachel Rose: Wil-O-Wisp/The Future Fields Commission"], Philadelphia Museum of Art, Retrieved 28 July 2018. ==Awards== Rose won the illy Present Future Prize at Artissima 2014{{cite web| url=http://www.artnews.com/2014/11/10/rachel-rose-wins-the-2014-illy-present-future-prize-at-artissima/| title=Rachel Rose wins the 2014 illy Present Future prize at Artissima| author=Alex Greenberger| date=10 November 2014| publisher=ArtNews| access-date=12 July 2016}} and the Frieze Artist Award for site-specific installations by emerging artists at the London fair.[https://news.artnet.com/art-world/rachel-rose-whitney-museum-show-348344 Artnet news: "Rachel Rose Explores the Wonders of the Cosmos in Her First US Solo Show" by Sarah Cascone] October 30, 2015{{cite web| url=http://www.artspace.com/magazine/interviews_features/meet_the_artist/rachel-rose-frieze-whitney-interview-53180 | title=Animal Architecture: A Q&A With Frieze Artist Award Winner Rachel Rose | author=Dylan Kerr | date=12 October 2015| publisher=Artspace | access-date=12 July 2016}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sJ4rRRq24eg Serpentine Galleries: "Rachel Rose talks about her exhibition, Palisades, at the Serpentine Sackler Gallery from 1 October to 8 November"] October 6, 2015 *[http://www.contemporaryartdaily.com/2014/10/rachel-rose-at-high-art/ Contemporary Art Daily: "Rachel Rose at High Art"] October 6, 2014" {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rose, Rachel}} revision.comment: distinguish:Restructuring
revision.text:
{{no footnotes|date=August 2011}} {{distinguish|Restructuring}}
'''Reconstruction''' in [[law]] refers typically to the transfer of a company's (or several companies') business to a new company. The old company will get put into liquidation, and shareholders will agree to take shares of equivalent value in the new company.
In [[UK company law]], the governing provisions are in the [[Insolvency Act 1986]], ss. 110–111. The sanction of a court is not required (unlike under a so-called "[[scheme of arrangement]]", which could or creditors). Yet if a shareholder objects, he or she may require a cash payment instead of shares. Creditors who object to have their debts transferred to a new company can demand satisfactions during the old company's liquidation.
Small private companies, family companies and investment trusts often use the procedure. The purposes can vary, from changing the objects of the business, varying share class rights, or reorganize before a [[demerger]] takes place.
==See also== *[[Mergers and acquisitions]] *[[Bankruptcy]]
==References== *Len Sealy and [[Sarah Worthington]] (2007) ''Cases and Materials in Company law'', 8th Ed., Oxford University Press *Paul Davies (2008) ''Gower's Modern Company Law'', 8th Ed., Sweet and Maxwell
[[Category:Corporate law]] [[Category:Mergers and acquisitions]] [[Category:Business terms]]

{{Infobox officeholder |image = Ruth Hanna McCormick.jpg |state = [[Illinois]] |district = {{ushr|IL|AL|at-large}} |term_start = March 4, 1929 |term_end = March 4, 1931
Seat A |predecessor = [[Henry Riggs Rathbone|Henry Rathbone]] |successor = [[William H. Dieterich|William Dieterich]] |birthname = Ruth Hanna |birth_date = {{birth date|1880|3|27}} |birth_place = [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]], [[United States|U.S.]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1944|12|31|1880|3|27}} |death_place = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], [[United States|U.S.]] |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |spouse = [[Joseph M. McCormick|Joseph McCormick]] (1903–1925)
[[Albert G. Simms|Albert Simms]] (1931–1944) |children = 3, including [[Bazy Tankersley]] |parents = [[Mark Hanna]]
Charlotte Rhodes }} '''Ruth McCormick Simms''' (née '''Ruth Hanna'''; March 27, 1880 – December 31, 1944) was a [[United States House of Representatives|United States Representative]] from [[Illinois]] and active in the [[women's suffrage]] movement. ==Early life and education== Ruth Hanna McCormick Simms was the daughter of Senator [[Mark Hanna]] and the wife of Senator [[Joseph M. McCormick|Joseph Medill McCormick]] and later of Congressman [[Albert Gallatin Simms]], hence her maiden name, Ruth Hanna, and name upon death, Ruth Hanna McCormick Simms, are also seen in the literature. McCormick was born in [[Cleveland, Ohio]] where she attended [[Hathaway Brown School]]. Later, she attended [[The Masters School]] in [[Dobbs Ferry, New York]] and the [[Miss Porter's School]] in [[Farmington, Connecticut]]. She owned and operated a [[Dairy farming|dairy]] and breeding farm near [[Byron, Illinois]] and was the publisher and president of the [[Rockford Consolidated Newspapers]] in [[Rockford, Illinois]]. In 1903 she married [[Joseph M. McCormick|Joseph "Medill" McCormick]]. They had three children: *[[Bazy Tankersley|Ruth "Bazy" McCormick Miller Tankersley]], (1921–2013) She was publisher of the Washington Times-Herald and founded [[Al-Marah Arabians]], a breeding and training farm for [[Arabian horse]]s now in [[Tucson, Arizona]], which is still operating.{{cite book |title=... and Ride Away Singing |last=Parkinson |first=Mary Jane |year=1998 |publisher=Arabian Horse Owners Foundation |isbn=978-1-930140-00-4 }} *Katrina McCormick (1913–2011), who married Courtland Dixon Barnes, Jr.{{cite news|last=McCormick|first=Katrina|title=Katrina McCormick Weds Courtland Dixon Barnes, Jr.|url=http://www.tarzan.org/pdf/19350615.pdf|accessdate=10 March 2013|newspaper=Syracuse Herald|date=June 15, 1935}} *John Medill McCormick, called "Johnny," died in a mountain-climbing accident in 1938. Medill served in both the [[United States House of Representatives]] and [[United States Senate]] prior to his death at age 47 on February 25, 1925.{{cite news |title= National Affairs: Medill McCormick |date= March 9, 1925 |work= [[Time (magazine)|Time magazine]] |url= http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,751256,00.html |accessdate= January 9, 2011 }} Although not publicized as such at the time, his death was considered a suicide.{{CongBio |M000369 |inline=please}} == Career == Ruth McCormick served as the chairman of the first woman's executive committee of the [[Republican National Committee]], and an associate member of the national committee 1919-1924, in the latter year becoming the first elected national committeewoman from Illinois and served until 1928. She was an active worker for the suffrage amendment from 1913 until the [[United States Constitution]] was amended. From 1913 to 1914, she served as head of the [[United States congressional committee|Congressional Committee]] for the [[National American Woman Suffrage Association]] (NAWSA). She took over leadership from [[Alice Paul]], who went on to form the [[Congressional Union]] as a separate national suffrage organization. During her time as leader of the Congressional Committee, she produced an eight-reel [[melodrama]] ''Your Girl and Mine'', which was intended to help gain support for the suffrage movement. The film never circulated broadly, despite critical praise from contemporary film reviewers, because the distribution agreement between NAWSA and the [[World Film Company]] fell apart shortly after the premiere in 1914 and the film was confined to private screenings. McCormick was elected as a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] to the [[71st United States Congress|Seventy-first Congress]] and served from March 4, 1929 to March 3, 1931 for the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]], at-large from Illinois. She defeated [[Charles S. Deneen]] in the 1930 Republican primary, but lost the November election to James Hamilton Lewis. She resumed her newspaper interests. In 1932, she married [[Albert Gallatin Simms]], of [[New Mexico]], who was also a Member of the Seventy-first Congress and resided in [[Albuquerque, New Mexico]].http://history.house.gov/People/Listing/M/McCORMICK,-Ruth-Hanna-(M000372)/ She moved to New Mexico with Simms to a ranch in northern Albuquerque. The property would become [[Los Poblanos Historic Inn & Organic Farm|Los Poblanos]], designed by [[John Gaw Meem]] in the [[Pueblo Revival architecture|Pueblo Revival Style]]. In 1932, she founded Sandia School, later becoming the [[Sandia Preparatory School]]. In 1938, she founded [[Manzano Day School]]. [[Albuquerque Academy]]'s land was donated by the Simms' and [[Albuquerque Little Theatre]] was also founded by Ruth.{{Cite book|title = New Mexico Chiles: History, Legend and Lore|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=xIUcCgAAQBAJ|publisher = Arcadia Publishing|date = 2015-07-20|isbn = 9781625853530|first = Kelly|last = Urig}} She ran a radio station and two newspapers in this period and later purchased a 250,000–acre cattle and sheep ranch in Colorado. She developed [[pancreatitis]] following a fall from a horse in 1944, and died in [[Chicago, Illinois]] on December 31, 1944. She was buried in Albuquerque, New Mexico. ==Family tree== {{McCormick Chicago family tree}} ==See also== {{Portal|Biography}} *[[Women in the United States House of Representatives]] *[[Woman's World's Fair]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Sources== {{CongBio|M000372}} *Miller, Kristie. ''Ruth Hanna McCormick: A Life in Politics, 1880-1944''. Albuquerque: University of New Mexico Press, 1992. *Miller, Kristie. "Ruth Hanna McCormick and the Senatorial Election of 1930." ''Illinois Historical Journal'', 81 (Autumn 1988): 191-210. *[[Karen Hasara|Hasara, Karen]]. "[http://www.lib.niu.edu/1993/ii930728.html McCormick unsung heroine in U.S. politics]." ''Illinois Issues''. XIX. 7 (July 1993): 28. *Shore, Amy. "Producing a National Suffrage Imaginary." Suffrage and the Silver Screen. Unpublished Dissertation: New York University, 2003. ==External links== {{commons category|Ruth Hanna McCormick}} *{{Find a Grave|6886257}} *Patrick, Jeanette. "[https://www.womenshistory.org/education-resources/biographies/ruth-hanna-mccormick-simms "Ruth Hanna McCormick"]. National Women's History Museum. 2016. {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-hs}} {{s-bef|before=[[Henry Riggs Rathbone|Henry Rathbone]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Member of the [[List of United States Representatives from Illinois|U.S. House of Representatives]]
from [[Illinois's at-large congressional district]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2017}} [[File:Shameel Joosub - 2018 (cropped).jpg|thumb|Shameel Joosub in 2018 ]] '''Mohamed Shameel Joosub''' is a South African businessman, the CEO of [[Vodacom]], a South African mobile communications company with over 55 million customers, since March 2013.<ref name="bloomberg1">{{cite web|author=Mohamed Shameel Joosub |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/profiles/people/16370984-mohamed-shameel-aziz-joosub |title=Mohamed Shameel Joosub, Vodacom Group Ltd: Profile & Biography |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=15 May 2017}}</ref>
Joosub has a [[Bachelor of Accountancy|Bachelor of Accounting Science]] from the [[University of South Africa]], and an [[MBA]] from the [[University of Southern Queensland]].<ref name="bloomberg1"/>
He was mentored by [[Alan Knott-Craig (Senior)|Alan Knott-Craig]], the founder of Vodacom, who was later the CEO of rival operator [[Cell C]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leader.co.za/article.aspx?s=1&f=1&a=4257 |title=Game on for Shameel Joosub, CEO Vodacom |publisher=Leader.co.za |date=14 February 2013 |accessdate=15 May 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Joosub, Shameel}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:South African businesspeople]] [[Category:South African chief executives]]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Siegfried Bettmann | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1863|4|18|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Nuremberg]], [[German Confederation]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1951|9|23|1863|4|18|df=y}} | death_place = | nationality =German | residence = [[Coventry]], [[Warwickshire]], England UK | occupation = Cycle, motorcycle and car manufacturer | salary = | networth = | spouse = Annie Meyrick | website = | footnotes = | children = }} '''Siegfried Bettmann''' was a bicycle, motorcycle and car manufacturer and initiator of the [[Triumph Engineering Co Ltd|Triumph Motorcycle Company]]. In 1914 he established the Annie Bettmann Foundation to help young people start businesses<ref name="Gloria" /> Triumph became one of the most famous motorcycle trade-names of the world.<ref name="Triumph over adversity">{{cite web|url=http://www.youricons.macrojuice.com/content/view/233/132/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080907115305/http://www.youricons.macrojuice.com/content/view/233/132/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=7 September 2008|title=Triumph over adversity|accessdate=5 October 2008}}</ref>
==Early life==
Born in 1863 in [[Nuremberg]], [[German Confederation|Germany]], Siegfried Bettmann moved to [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|Britain]] in 1885,<ref name="Triumph">{{cite web|url=http://www.triumph.co.uk/australia/1531.aspx|title=About Triumph|accessdate=5 October 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821040348/http://www.triumph.co.uk/australia/1531.aspx|archivedate=21 August 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and settled in [[Coventry]], [[Warwickshire]]. He found work with Kelly & Co. compiling foreign directories for their publications. After six months, he obtained a job with the White Sewing Machine Co. as a translator and worked as the company's sales representative in [[northern Europe]]. Fluent in several languages, he perfected his English, married a local woman, Annie Meyrick (known as Millie).<ref name="Gloria">{{cite web|url=http://www.hellfire-corner.demon.co.uk/terryreeves.htm|title=Triumph and Gloria|accessdate=5 October 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090108172730/http://www.hellfire-corner.demon.co.uk/terryreeves.htm|archivedate=8 January 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Business==
Bettmann founded S. Bettmann & Co and started selling bicycles by the name 'Triumph' from premises in London. In 1886, Bettmann sought a more general name, and the company became known as the [[Triumph Cycle Co. Ltd.|Triumph Cycle Company]]. A year later, the company registered as the New Triumph Co. Ltd., with funding from the [[Dunlop Pneumatic Tyre Company]]. In that year, Bettmann was joined by a native from Papenburg named Johann Moritz Schulte, as a partner. Schulte encouraged Bettmann to transform Triumph into a manufacturing company, and in 1888 Bettmann purchased a site in Coventry using money lent by his and Schulte's families. The company began producing the first Triumph-branded bicycles in 1889. In 1896, Triumph initiated a subsidiary, [[Triumph (TWN)|Orial TWN (Triumph Werke Nuremberg)]] a [[:de:Triumph (D)|German subsidiary]] for cycle production in his native city.
In 1902 the company diversified into making motorcycles at their works in Much Park Street. In 1902 the first Triumph motorcycle was developed. It was a strengthened bicycle with a 2.25 bhp [[Minerva]] engine.<ref name="Triumph"/> Once the business grew the purchased engines were replaced with their own and in 1907 the company expanded into a new factory in Priory Street, in premises of a former mill. [[Image:Triumph 1922 H 1.jpg|thumb|left|1922 Triumph H 1]] At the beginning of [[World War I]] the War Office called a meeting of [[Coventry]] industrialists at St Mary's Hall and asked them to put their resources at the disposal of the military and two weeks after Britain had declared war on Germany, Bettmann received a telephone call from Capt. C. V. Holdsworth of the Army Service Corps, (who later became Triumph's managing director) with an order for a hundred Triumph motorcycles for the [[British Expeditionary Force (World War I)|BEF]] who were soon to go to France. Despite being a Saturday afternoon, Bettmann and his staff worked non-stop to crate the required motorcycles and by Sunday evening they were delivered to Coventry railway station in time for the evening train.<ref name="Gloria" /> The British Army subsequently placed large orders for the Triumph 550 cc Model H and by 1918 they were Britain's largest motorcycle manufacturer. [[Image:Triumph.Gloria.jpg|thumb|right|[[Triumph Gloria]]]] In 1921 Bettmann further diversified into car production and bought the Dawson Car Company to produce the Triumph 10/20. In 1927 he developed the Triumph Super 7 which sold well until 1934. In 1930 the company changed its name to the Triumph Motor Company and produced the Triumph Southern Cross and Gloria ranges. In 1936 the company had financial problems however and in 1936 the Triumph bicycle and motorcycle businesses were both sold. The motorcycle business was bought by [[Jack Sangster]] of [[Ariel Motorcycles]] to become [[Triumph Engineering Co Ltd]].
==Later life==
Siegfried Bettmann's success enabled him to become President of the Coventry [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal]] Association. A [[Freemason]] and founder member of Coventry's [[Chamber of Commerce]], he was also a [[Justice of the Peace]] and in 1913 became [[Mayor of Coventry]], the first non-British subject to have the position.<ref name="Gloria" />
His German origins resulted in him being removed from this position on the beginning of the [[First World War]]. <ref>{{Cite ODNB|id=46628|title=Siegfried Bettmann}}</ref>.
In 1914 Siegfried Bettmann founded the Annie Bettmann Foundation with his wife to help young Coventry men and women between the ages of eighteen and forty who wished to start a business. Preference was given to ex-servicemen and the fund, which is still in existence, was extended subsequently to include grants for further education.<ref name="Gloria" /> Bettmann also commissioned a memorial for the 66 employees of the Triumph company killed in action during the First World War, built in Coventry's London Road cemetery in 1921.<ref name="Gloria" />
The Triumph Motorcycle Company became one of the most famous motorcycle marques of the world and Bettmann retained an association with the company until his death.<ref name="Triumph over adversity"/> Siegfried Bettmann died on 23 September 1951 at his home "Elm Bank", Stoke Park, [[Coventry]].<ref>Death notice published in ''The Times'', 25 September 1951</ref>. In 2015 the Coventry Society installed a [[Blue Plaque]] onto this residence.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sigfried Bettman's Home Gets Blue Plaque|url=http://www.coventrysociety.org.uk/news/article/bettmanns-home-gets-blue-plaque.html|publisher=Coventry Society|accessdate=12 February 2017}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Triumph Engineering]] * [[Triumph Motor Company]] * [[Standard Motor Company]] * [[Triumph (TWN)]] * [[Triumph Cycle|Triumph Cycle Co. Ltd]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://wiki.transport-museum.com/(S(wzvcvfbkgpghwi45vcaeypef))/Siegfried%20Bettmann.ashx Biography at transport-museum.com] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140324172624/http://www.coventrysquared.com/facts-fiction-and-famous-freemasons/ Biography at CoventrySquared]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bettmann, Siegfried}} [[Category:1863 births]] [[Category:1951 deaths]] [[Category:Motorcycle manufacturers of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:German businesspeople]] [[Category:People from Nuremberg]] [[Category:German expatriates in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:German founders of automobile manufacturers]] [[Category:Mayors of Coventry]] [[Category:German Freemasons]]
